title: Whine and No Love
text:
I was hoping this book would be a legitimate critique of the influence of a few wine writers like Robert Parker on the wine business. Instead, the "Battle for Wine and Love" contains a narrative of Ms. Feiring's personal issues disguised as a combination autobiography and manifesto related to her job as a writer.

The reason for not giving this book just one star, is that despite the annoying, self-indulgent nonsense, she does make one valid point. The wine industry, including both large and small producers, are modifying their products to achieve high ratings from Parker, the Wine Spectator, and other influential publications. As a consequence, more wines are emphasizing fruit over complexity, and the uniqueness of regional character may be falling way to a globalization of taste. But in her discussion, she fails to recognize that wine is a product to be created, sold, and consumed. The small producers for whom she has such affection produce wine to make a living; a fact that seems to escape the author.

Burying this point in a sniveling diatribe that is as much about her upbringing and depressing love life (although there seems to be very little love involved)completely ruins what could have been an interesting read.

Feiring sets up Robert Parker as some kind of evil force; but, when she interviews him she neither provides the full interview nor adequately captures the essence of it. She makes it clear at the end of the chapter containing the interview that she really wasn't looking for a dialogue, but wanted to just tell him off.

It is the author's self righteous tone that most diminishes the value of this book. She claims to have a superior palate; she finds her surprisingly loyal friends to be an embarrassment; and she seems surprised why she has real difficulties with relationships.

After completing this book, I poured a much needed glass of wine and took the time to enjoy it. I have no idea if anyone rated it.

title: Good first book for those just starting the road to living debt free. Falls short for most others
text:
Not much originality in this book to be honest. If you've read articles on debt repayment, none of what Mr. Ramsey has to say should be new to you.

The idea of a debt snowball is ONE approach to tackling your outstanding debts. As he himself admits, it is not the most number-driven approach. Attacking the highest interest debt first makes the most sense, while the debt snowball method takes care of smaller amounts of debt offering small, quick victories. He likens it to a marathon- it is tough to go from walking less than a mile to finishing a marathon. Basically, celebrate the small victories even if it does cost you a little more in the end.

My major problem with his approach, and many others, is the emergency fund. It is essential for a family to have a "rainy day" fund. Bad times will happen. It is not a matter of if, but when. Mr. Ramsey advocates saving $1000 and using the rest of your available money that is not already earmarked to tackle your debt. If you have a small, unexpected expense crop up, use your emergency fund and stop repaying the debt until you've reestablished your emergency fund. Sounds like a solid plan. It keeps you from borrowing more money when faced with life's unforeseen circumstances.

What happens when the emergency surpasses that $1000 mark? Sure you could reduce the money you're repaying on your debt, but that assumes you will have enough to cover the expense. What if you don't? You'll be back to borrowing money, the very thing you were trying to avoid. Now, I'm not advocating amassing a huge emergency fund while your debt continues to pile up, but 1,000 seems extremely low for most families. In Mr. Ramsey's defense he does say to eventually build up your emergency fund to a 3 or 6 month reserve, but it is the in between that makes me nervous. Why not build more of your emergency fund first and then tackle the debt? That way you would have some cushion and not need to worry as much about things cropping up unexpectedly that will likely surpass a $1000 price tag.

title: Conflicting Chapters
text: Hailey Dean is a top notch prosecuting attorney who has never lost a case.  She experiences "burnout" when her most recent case reveals a hardened killer (Clint Cruise) of 10 victims by strangulation.  He is up on a charge of an eleventh victim; however, he admits guilt (to the reader only) of the first 10 but not number 11.  Hailey prosecutes him and wins her case.  She then decides she has had enough of the dregs of society and moves to NYC from Atlanta to begin a new career as a psychologist.  Two years pass and Cruise is set free due to a political move by a corrrupt Judge looking to become Governor and following the orders of the man in charge of getting him to the Governor's mansion.  Now with Cruise out, Hailey is being followed and her patients are meeting untimely deaths.  The climax is an unexpected twist as to "who did it."  I wasn't particularly crazy about the method of writing going from one storyline to another every other chapter.  The whole story regarding saving the beaches of St. Simons Island, GA was a drag and took away from the main storyline.  We do see a subtle link at the end to the main character but it seemed unnecessary to the main story.  Had Ms. Grace stuck to the murder plot and embellished on that throughout the book, I believe it would have enhanced the continuity of the story and made it a much better read.

title: Heyer and Austen need not worry
text:
(Gratefully borrowed from the Greater Phoenix Digital Library, which is why this is not a verified purchase.)

It's possible my expectations were set too high, but wow, what a letdown. Whoever wrote the book description, "a novel to make Jane Austen proud and Georgette Heyer envious," had delusions of grandeur. Jude Morgan can write well, but his skills of characterization need improvement; his characters fall flat. Here's what I mean:

POSSIBLE SPOILERS...

First, there is no hero in the novel. Three possibilities for the role don't pass muster. One, modeled after Darcy, I suppose, is cold, haughty and reserved, all right, but his character is too disgusting to redeem. Sensing this, the author merely throws in an equally-frigid character he can win more easily. Another, whose sullenness the heroine for some unfathomable reason finds attractive, is meant to be Heathcliff-like, or Byronic, or something, but instead of charming, he comes across as pouting and angry for no clear reason. Any charming aspect of his character is too poorly conveyed by the author to be noticeable. And a third one is such a dull wooden character that I'm not at all surprised that the heroine never had a clue he felt anything at all for her. I was still debating that myself, as the novel ended.

An attempt to include characters whose quirks can reliably amuse us is a little more successful, but the most humorous ones are near the beginning of the story and are dropped as the book progresses. One would have thought that Mrs. Lappage, for example, carefully drawn at the beginning of the novel, would play an ongoing role, but she disappears 35% into the novel. Another promising character, Miss Rose, a female Uriah Heep, is, regrettably, dropped after only a few memorable contributions to conversation.

Caricature and subtlety do not work well together; therefore, I assume Mr. Morgan did not intend to call more attention to the quirks of Sophie, who perhaps was intended to be a less disingenuous Isabella Thorpe. Whatever his intention, Sophie is not clearly developed. Nor is her mother, whose character, I think, was supposed to be a more easily pleased Mrs. Bennet, any more fully-realized.

Two villains in the novel also suffer from lack of character development. Suspension of disbelief for the femme fatale is especially difficult, and the couple's longterm lifestyles and machinations are not believable.

A secondary character, sister of one of the supposed heroes, intended to be sympathetically portrayed, I think, is yet another whose personality is barely developed and whose action in the plot is lacking.

The author's wry observations, and the graceful writing, are striking. Perhaps that makes the letdown worse. I started reading this novel wondering how I could find his other novels, since so few are in e-book format, or even in paper form in my library. Having read this novel, I am less inclined to search for any others.

title: I enjoyed the winemaking details
text:
The Vineyard at Painted Moon was the April selection for the Page-turners Book Club at the Kewaunee Public Library.

Mackenzie has the job that she loves working at her husband’s family vineyard. She blends delicious wines that attract a lot of customers. Her world comes crashing down when her husband wants a divorce. What should she do? Stay and keep working for the vineyard or strike out on her own?

I usually love Mallery’s novels, but while I read through this one quickly, I didn’t love it. I enjoyed Mackenzie’s journey and her gumption to strike out on her own. I liked the story of the various family members. I overall though just felt sad for the destruction of the marriage. The novel started out happy with Mackenzie’s mother-in-law Barbara’s engagement, and then Barbara turned into a one-dimensional villain. It was too drastic of a change to me. Mackenzie’s new romance was not very well developed and felt tacked on at the end. I did enjoy all of the details of wine making and thought that was fascinating.

Overall, The Vineyard at Painted Moon was a so-so novel for me.

Book Source: Kewaunee Public Library. Thank-you!

title: The new social structure is in trouble  🙄
text:
3.5 stars

In Pierce Brown's 'Red Rising Trilogy' which precedes this book, humans - who had colonized the entire Solar System - were separated into caste-like Color categories. The ruling "Golds" were on top and the low-level "Reds" were on the bottom. The Reds were essentially slaves, who had short brutal lives in the underground mines of Mars. Other Color groups worked as medical personnel, soldiers, police, artists, sex workers, bureaucrats, household help, and so on.

The original trilogy revolves around Darrow, who was born a Red. After being surgically transformed to look like a Gold, Darrow infiltrated Gold society and - after rising through the ranks - became known as Darrow au Andromedus of Lykos.

Darrow eventually led a revolution that overthrew Gold rule. This led to the establishment of a democracy that would (theoretically) allow all Color groups to have equal rights. Thus, at the end of the trilogy I thought things in the Solar System were running down the right track.

NOT SO FAST!!

In 'Iron Gold' - the first book of Pierce Brown's new series -it's ten years after the revolution. A Solar Republic has been established, with an 'all Color' Senate on Luna (Earth's moon). The Senate debates and enacts legislation, with input from all sides. The head of the Senate, and elected Sovereign of the Republic, is Virginia au Augustus - a Gold who happens to be Darrow's wife. Darrow is the military leader of the Republic, and he's in big trouble.

After the revolution, Gold factions retained control of Mercury, Venus, and the Outer Rim. The Golds hate Darrow, whom they consider a Red usurper, and call him the 'Slave King.'

To wrest control of Mercury from the Golds, Darrow unleashed a massive bombing attack on the small planet - called an 'Iron Rain.' This was successful, but resulted in immeasurable damage and cost hundreds of millions of lives. The Senate didn't give permission for the Iron Rain and plans to put Darrow on trial. However, Darrow has no intention of allowing this to happen.

To further peace in the Solar System, Darrow feels compelled to free Venus, which is under the thumb of Gold leader Magnus au Grimmus, also known as the Ash Lord. Darrow plans to kill the Ash Lord, a feat that's almost impossible since Magnus never leaves his impregnable fortress home.

Darrow devises a complex plan to slay the Ash Lord, but he must first escape from Luna with his most loyal supporters.....leaving his wife and their son Pax behind. Darrow is torn between his duties as a warrior and his responsibilities as a husband and father, and this haunts him throughout the novel.

Though Darrow is an important protagonist in this new series, other characters also take center stage. These include:

Ephraim ti Horn, a Gray who fought for the revolution, but became disillusioned after his husband was brutally murdered. Grief-stricken and angry, Ephraim left the military to become a professional thief. Ephraim recruited a small group of helpers, and now accepts commissions to steal specific items such as artworks, weapons, and so on. When a vicious crime lord hires Ephraim to steal some very valuable commodities, big trouble ensues.

*****

Lyria of Lagalos, an 18-year-old Red girl who was liberated from the Martian mines after the rebellion. Lyria and her extended family were placed in a refugee camp on the surface of the planet, and promised assistance from the Republic. The administration didn't come through, however, and Lyria lost most of her family to a terrorist attack.

When the government finally sends troops to Mars, Lyria rescues an injured Gold warrior named Kavax au Telemanus from drowning. The wealthy man repays Lyria by taking her into his household on Luna, where she works as a servant. Uneducated, naïve, and lonely, Lyria falls under the influence of a dapper, charming older man. Once again, this leads to trouble.

*****

Lysander au Lune, a 20-year-old Gold who's the grandson of Octavia au Lune - the Sovereign who ruled the Empire before the rebellion. After his grandmother was killed, Lysander was taken under the wing of Cassius au Bellona - a Gold who was once Darrow's friend....but is now his mortal enemy.

As Lysander and Cassius are wandering around the Solar System in their armored craft they come upon a stranded ship in deep space. This leads to the rescue of a young Gold woman named Seraphina au Raa, who's the daughter of Romulus au Raa - leader of the Outer Rim. As a result, Lysander and Cassius - instead of being thanked - are made prisoners of Seraphina's mother, the merciless Dido au Raa.

Lysander and Cassius learn that Dido is planning a massive attack on the inner planets, to try to re-establish Gold rule. The newcomers can either assist with the assault.....or face the consequences. Tough call!

*****

The book is chock full of clever tactics, stealthy maneuvers, and deadly battles, and the characters have all manner of futuristic weapons and protective armor - which I picture as flexible 'Iron Man' suits. Pierce Brown populates the book with a large array of characters, including several favorites from the Red Rising Trilogy, such as: Sevro au Barca (Darrow's best friend); Victra au Barca (Sevro's wife); Dancer (Darrow's former mentor, now a powerful Senator); Kieran (Darrow's brother); Rhonna (Darrow's niece); and more.

The author wisely includes a list of characters at the beginning of the book, with thumbnail descriptions, which I found very useful. Pierce Brown also provides a map of the Solar System, with the location of the various factions, which helped me orient myself in the Solar Republic.

For me, 'Iron Gold' didn't stir the same positive emotions as the original trilogy. In the first three books I cheered on the abused Reds who were struggling for freedom and equality. In this new trilogy, the narcissistic, entitled Golds are scheming to re-take (what they think is ) their rightful place in society.....and I'm not on board for that.

I almost wish Pierce Brown had just started a new series that takes place in a different world with new characters.

Nevertheless, the story is well-written, exciting, and suspenseful, and I recommend it to fans of science fiction/adventure tales. The book could be read as a standalone, but for maximum pleasure it's best to read the Red Rising Trilogy first.

title: Incredibly Awful Book
text:
It started off well...then it all went downhill from there. Maggie owns an antique shop. But she knows that material possessions mean nothing. But yet she knows all about antique and historical items, as that is how she makes her living. This doesn't mesh. Her daughter, Jenna, dumps her baby daughter "Cody," off on Maggie, when she, Jenna is eighteen. Maggie is forty. She tells her maid that forty is too old to have and raise a child. All women forty and up who've had children must not have gotten that memo. Maggie also does not have much money. Yet she has a maid (or is she a live-in housekeeper? not really clear) for twenty-something years....longer than her daughter is old...so she had a maid before she even had a child!

Then it goes off into all this dark voodoo baby sacrificing black magic Satan worshiping religious stuff. Absolutely over the top. The author apparently watched way too much "Geraldo." I had to laugh when I read about the nanny with the two large black Alsatian dogs and the white Abyssian cat - and they all walk together - or perhaps "stalk" is a better word - looking down their noses at whatever peons they may encounter. The nanny apologizes to the animals for not have any skinned babies in the basement, as they prefer them skinned. Is a baby's skin really that tough?

Of course there is a priest and a cop, and of course they BOTH fall madly in love with Maggie, despite their pasts, wonderful Maggie brings them hope of a fresh life anew. I gave up halfway through. I'm sure it all ended well!

text: I read this book and finished not knowing what I read. No clarity on what the plot or story line was. It was all over the place and had too many assumptions that you understood what they just learned or their line of thinking. Never even got a real sense of why they were looking for Jack or how their "boss" seemingly already knew everything and seemed totally irrelevant to Jack Reacher, just that he was there 15 years ago. As a Jack Reacher/Lee Child fan, I felt cheated being pulled into this series and won't be following more.

title: Interesting but flat portrayal ...
text: Being a parent of an "Aspie" being married to an "Aspie" and having "Aspie" traits myself, it was obvious to me that the book was written by an observer of Asperger's Syndrome/Autism. The book was a great observation but failed to present the rich inner life of an "Aspie" ... The main character's inner life was presented as being as flat as his voice where in truth it is very likely it is rich with imagery ... maybe even too much and confusing imagery. Communication is the problem ... not the mind's ability to create.

title: The book was of no value to me.
text:
I really wasn't expecting it to be that helpful, but it was even less thorough than I anticipated. I have a modest Ed. Wusthof collection going back to a few 1814-1895 knives, several 1895 - 1920's, and then pre-WWII to present, roughly 100 knives total. The books coverage however, is abysmal.

There are three pages on Anton Wingen, for example, that was in business 1888-1993. For Ed. Wusthof, a company that is family owned for over 200 years, from 1814 to present day, there's 3/4 of a page. That meager listing leaves out the 2 earliest company marks. With even my limited knowledge, I could list several pages of maker's marks for the company, with approximate year ranges, designs, and materials.

I won't try to return it because the seller did his job with speedy delivery, and there are no promises in the description as to what it will do for me. I'm commenting just to warn other users to check it out a little more carefully, it's far from a 'bible' of German cutlery.

title: Lovely, likeable
text: THIS IS AN EDIT OF THE ORIGINAL REVIEW:  APOLOGY TO ALL WHO READ THE ORIGINIAL REVIEW: SHOULD HAVE PAID MORE ATTENTION TO THE OTHER REVIEWERS!  This may be the most expensive book and horrible time-waster I've ever seen. I was so excited when first getting the book with such great outfits, I didn't pay enough attention to the back of the book with the "patterns". Just saw the sturdy paper there and planned on copying on printer.. Big mistake. The "full-sized patterns" are a horror.The patterns are on 20" x 30" paper, laid out to conserve space, and impossible to fit onto a printer. The pattern pieces are arranged so poorly that you'll be lucky to get 2 pieces on an 8x12 sheet of paper. Many of them are too large even for that and must be pieced together for the full size. There are 98 pieces --it will take a full cartridge to print them. Plastic sheets for the pieces? $$$. Transfer paper? probably 40-50 sheets. The best description I can give to the way the patterns were done is: CHEAP,CHINCY,DUMB. ORIGINAL REVIEW:  First-had ordered the book, Doll Fashion Studio: Sew 20 Seasonal Outfits for Your 18-Inch Doll, from another seller for a slightly lower price, but it was backordered for 6-8 weeks. Amazon to the rescue--ordered,Prime, and a few days later, it was on my doorstep. Instant love. Yes, it does have 1 drawback, hence the 4 stars instead of 5. The patterns are printed on both sides of the pages, but it's such a minor annoyance, you'll forgive Joan Hinds. Also, I plan on making templates of the pattern pieces, so tracing them out won't bother me a bit. You'll really like the fact that the pattern pieces are on sturdy paper at the back of the book. You'll be able to utilize the instuctions (really liberal with pictures of all the pieces) without leaving the instruction pages for the outfit. The book also answered another question I've been trying to decide on what to craft for St. Jude and other children's charities. It has several projects which will be great for dolls, but can also be adapted for little ones undergoing treatment. Just wish I could have afforded the DVD. Hope everyone will have as much fun as I plan to have with this great book. God Bless.

title: Sea Star: Orphan of Chincoteague
text:
After reading Misty of Chincoteague, anyone could become enamoured with the ponies of Assateague island. That being said, this book is kind of a let down after that. While it was still well written for children and does envelop the horse culture that is Chincoteague, the story almost seems incomplete and not very fleshed out.

Its the next Pony Penning day at Chinconteague and before all the wild ponies of Assateague can be driven over to the island, Paul and Maureen are approached by some movie makers wanting to buy Misty, their pony they had gotten the year before. Misty is beloved to them and they have a hard time letting her go, but need the money to send their uncle to college and also think other children should be able to experience the wonderfulness that is Misty. With the emptiness that fills their hearts after letting her go, they need to find something to ease the pain. Luckily, they find an orphaned foal whom they call Sea Star and claim him for their very own. He doesn't want to eat however, and is not thriving very well. Maureen and Paul have to find a way to save him.

The characters in this book are not as fleshed out. Although they are the same as from the previous books, they just don't have as much warmth to them and even Grandpa Beebe seems a little less cheerful. Grandma Beebe gets a few more lines in this book which was nice to see, but still remains a minor character. The book mostly focuses on Paul and Maureen but they are often doing things rather than experiencing them and showing emotion (the exception being when they make the decision to sell Misty).

This book is still very well written for kids. Most of it is easy to read and understand and has a simplicity that even the younger ages can handle. There isn't anything offensive in this book and it is appropriate for all ages. I do find some flaws in the writing though, although a lot happens in this book there is scant description and the ending seemed incomplete. Another fifty pages or so would definitely help the book and bring the story along more.

It was an ok book, just not as good as some of Henry's others. I do look forward to reading some of her other books and always love a good horse story that appeals to adults and children alike.

Sea Star
Copyright 1949
174 pages including pictures

title: Very good story, but needs an editor
text: Aya Knight has a very good imagination and has written a fun, exciting adventure story.  Too bad her writing skills are not up to snuff.  Her grammar is fine, but I think she must write with a thesaurus, since many of her words have a similar definition to her intended meaning but the connotation is wrong.  For those that don't know the difference, they'll truly enjoy the book.  For those who have a better vocabulary, it will be very annoying, but not so annoying that it makes the book unreadable.  Hopefully, she'll give her next book to an editor to help fix wording problems because the story is worth the effort.

title: Highly Imaginative
text:
I chose to read From a Buick 8 by Stephen King as a Lovecraftian read. I had heard mixed opinions about the novel. Some people hated it, and other people felt it is very underrated, overlooked, and deserves more credit. In other words they love it. I have to say I am a bit torn as to my opinion, but maybe my review can shed some light.

From a Buick 8 is a story that focuses on the son of a deceased Pennsylvania State Trooper, and a mysterious Buick Roadmaster that shows up in their town. Ned is the son of the late Trooper Curtis Wilcox, and the men and women of Troop D decide to sit down and talk with Ned. The aged Troopers tell Ned a tale that leaves him with more questions. Will their complete story answer questions from days gone by? Will the Buick’s mysteries be revealed? Will more death ensue?

I love King’s writing, and of course his story telling and descriptiveness is amazing. From a Buick 8 is a book I feel may grow on you in time. I really enjoyed the telling of the story that spanned from the late 70’s to 2001. It was also interesting how it was told by the older Troop D Troopers. A lot of the descriptions require a lot of imagination. (When it comes to the Buick). I am also torn by the ending.

Overall I give From a Buick 8 by Stephen King three and a half stars out of five stars. I really enjoyed the book, but it wasn’t my absolute favorite. It definitely is a book that makes you think, and use your imagination. There was an issue I saw where King said in one chapter that Curt was the one Trooper who didn’t Smoke when they went to the diner. Then a few chapters later it said his wife nagged him to quit smoking for years. That bothered me. I also felt a little bummed at the end outcome even though the journey was fantastic. Until next time, my friends.

title: Not what I needed for students
text: I was a volunteer at a public library, and I was teaching english to spanish speakers. I got this to help them learning English, but it was not what we needed. I found a couple other books that were helpful. I can't recommend this.

title: Another Forgetable Work In an Unremarkable Series
text:
From the back cover.

Beyond the Gates of Night

Protected by Warhorses and Battle Owls, the peaceful tunnelers fled the fury of Elundium's mob. Beyond the wildness of Underfall. Oaktangle and Sloeberry's people found refuge in the ruins of a great city, prowled by the shades of its long-dead inhabitants.

But now an ancient evil threatens the sovereign who spared the gentle ones. King Thane faces a dark horde even more ravenous than the Nightbeasts that once ripped open his realm.

The Master of Magic, Nevian, has recruited a blacksmith who can forge real weapons of war, to replace the mock armor with which the gentle people fled. But can a crippled boy and a runaway archer's son forge themselves into genuine Knights of Cadwor, and defeat the bitter wraiths gathering like smoke over embattled Elundium?

---------------------------------------

Overall not much happens in this book. Like the prior books its fee of surpises and the reader quickly becomes frustrated with the slow plodding pace of events. P

The ending will leave you hanging. And so you'll have to find the sequels Threads of Magic and The Siege of Candlebane Hall. Both of these books, which were never published in the US, are hard to hard to find, especially the Siege of Candlebane Hall.

My recommendation is to avoid this book.

title: An easy read
text:
Sarah Barthel's "House of Silence" hooked me on the premise that a young woman witnesses her fiance commit murder. Given the time period (1875) when women had few choices in society, the danger is heightened. What does the young woman do? In Isabelle Larkin's case, with her fiance denying what seems obvious, and pressure from her mother to continue with the wedding plans, she goes a risky route of faking mental illness which sends her to Bellevue sanitarium where a certain Mrs Lincoln is also staying post-assassination.

The writing is nice enough as is the evocation of the period. It moves along at an even pace with decent, if not memorable, characterization. As great as the set up is, I didn't feel particular suspense while I was reading. That said, it was an easy, serviceable read.

title: Forgettable
text: This is the first time such a thing has happened. I didn't make time to write a review of this mystery. And was caught in another book which took some time to complete. Last night, thought I'd catch up with reviewing and discovered that when I picked up "Veiled Revenge", I had literally forgotten everything about it. I just reread the first few pages, and in all honesty can say it was understandably forgettable. Don't waste time and money.

title: Dated, disappointing.
text: Although I'm a long-time fan of Hiassen's novels, this one left me disappointed.  It's very dated and full of cliches.  It struck me as long-winded and preaching many of themes Hiassen revisits in his stories.  By contrast, I found Stormy Weather to be a rollicking, fun novel -- and much more satisfying and believable in terms of good guys / bad guys in society.  In today's world, the bloody violence and wanton murder of innocents in Tourist Season don't seem as farcical as they might have been when first published.

title: CHANGED MY OPINION
text: I had rated this a 5 earlier, but now that I have it and have used it a bit more I needed to change it.  I use markers and pencils and due to the "new improved" paper used for this book, colors are dull looking, no vibrancy to them.  I do NOT like that.  True, you don't seem to need as much pressure to color but the colors are so blah.  And as I had said in my previous review, there are a LOT of what I'm calling wasted pictures; WHY would I take the time to color a page of nothing but different shaped leaves or a trail on two pages of vines???  I hope the next book goes back to the old paper and there will be more variety of pix to color.

title: Gets some things right, misses the rest
text:
When I lived in NYC and dealt with my share of roaches, mice, noise, lack of A/C, no elevator, erratic heating, gasoline fumes from downstairs, getting my car towed, sleeping in the car during street cleaning to hold my spot, paying a lot for everything - I have to say that I agreed with the title. It gets some things right, but misses the rest. Their focus on the sex and the city tour feels like it is written from the point of view of tourists visiting NYC, rather than ones who know it well. This book doesn't list the many common "horrors" (rent discounts) of apartment living. Where are the colourful stories of the homeless? The creative directions that people have given to tourists? A hipster or homeless identification guide? I'm not sure who the target audience is.

Being out of NYC and in visiting some other places, I have to say even with the pitfalls of NYC you can't fault its multiculturalism.

title: Disappointing

title: Useful references for superhero comic illustrators
text:
"Freehand Figure Drawing for Illustrators" would be better titled "Mannequin Figures from Any Angle." The book mostly provided reference illustrations rather than detailed instructions on drawing a figure without any reference. If you don't have a live model or photo reference, you can use this book to look up a variety of poses from a wide variety of angles (front, back, 3/4, high, low, etc.).

The author provided many reference illustrations: mannequins and parts of mannequins from different angles and anatomy labels for the ear, hand, foot, a full skeleton, and major muscles. He described in step-by-step detail how to draw a head, hand, and foot. He also described in a generalized, "it'll be about here" way how different angles affect the apparent placement or size of various features.

The author assumed a certain amount of previous experience in drawing figures. For example: in his first section, he explained perspective and how to draw a box in perspective. He then gave a two-step lesson: (1) a rotated box viewed from low perspective (2) a fully rendered figure in that box. I was hoping for help in drawing a mannequin correctly into that perspective box or through using perspective lines. That help is never provided beyond a few, brief tips.

The mannequins were all super-hero types (skinny women or muscled men) and many of the references were from extreme angles or of exaggerated movements. From this, I assume the book is really targeted at superhero comic illustrators, and it's probably quite useful for them. But I'm more interested in drawing normal humans in natural poses. I got some useful tips, but it's not really geared toward my interests.

I received this book as a review copy from the publisher.

title: Complexities are somewhat of a drag
text: This 2009 crme novel is the author's first book, and tells of a man who tells his newpaper delivery man (a character in his own right) that he has killed the woman who the carrier knows as his wife.  The book then details  extensively the investigation by the police and by the lawyers, the defendant's lawyer being hobbled by the defendant not speaking to her, though he writes notes.  When we get to the preliminary hearing there is some excitement, but the complexities of the case do not really intrigue.  The judge is portrayed as an uncool character, and did not impress me as a credible portrait of even a judge such as he is drawn.  There is a lot of Toronto local color, which I presume will make the story of greater interest to people in Toronto.  It did not do so for me, and I thought much of the book less than exciting, and some of the pretense at tension towards the end not very realistic.

title: unfortunately she fails so miserably by creating a love story that which does work & then goes to ...
text: Hollis Seamon's "Somebody Up There Hates You" is the story of Richard Casey a 17 y/o boy who is spending the final days of his life in a hospice unit with terminal cancer. He there meets Sylvie a 16 y/o girl across the hall who he develops an instant crush on. Set across a total of 10 days in 3 parts, Seamon tells a story that is so outlandish it's almost unbelievable. Instead of perhaps showing the more serious side of kids with cancer, she creates a character in Richie who pretends to be king, goes on a wild Halloween night excursion with his Uncle Phil & causes more mayhem than is typically allowable in a hospice or hospital setting. With Sylvie, we have a young woman who has an overprotective to the point of abusively, drunk father & whose one redeeming characteristic is her stubbornness & unwillingness to give up. If that were the theme presented throughout the book, then Seamon would accomplish what she set out to do, unfortunately she fails so miserably by creating a love story that which does work & then goes to an extreme to create a Hatfields & McCoys type setting in the hospital. While the characters themselves are believable for the most part, the storytelling is extremely uneven & is oversexualized for no reason at times. A big disappointment for a book that could've been so much more.

title: Unholy Mess
text:
I could say the writing is boring, cliched, unoriginal, cardboard characters, awful dialogue and romances juvenile but the REAL problem is the lack of a vocabulary for writing. This reeks of Google searches, other books, other films, making it up as you go. The stellar ratings for this "literature" is downright scary.

The writing is beyond boring, middle school level - everything is explained and it's obvious the "research" consists of Google searches and other sci-fi novels. We get rants against AI and regardless of gender or age dialogue is the same. In a hospital where people are chased, escape, get caught then wake up naked in glass boxes. The group - fireman, doctor, IT guy, mechanic, old man, little girls, blah blah are, of course, clueless. The hero / fireman is "limited" (his words) (Aspergers?). Mankind is dying (despite all the high tech) so a bunch of folks were chosen to [reserve humanity - wow, how original! One of the group attacks their guide, a nice man with answers because he thought something wasn't right and shock! The guide is an android.

To restart mankind they must find the right group (there are several) and avoid (PLOT REVEAL) poison air, getting stuck on an island, getting caught on a boat, figuring out coordinates from a list of wrong numbers (smile), finding an underground civilization, escaping, finding an undersea civilization (where deal old mom awaits out of 8 billion folks) and finally waking in a new world that is... Earth of 1961. Yes, it was Venus the whole time. The nuttiest aspect is that to save mankind they are made to solve a bunch of idiotic "clues". My Grade - F-

The front cover does have a pretty, colorful picture of Dora, but the inside of the book basically looks like someone photocopied pictures of Dora and Boots on a plain, white cotton sheet. title: A waste of $3.99
text:
This is by far one of the worse books I have read in a very long time. I am usually a very fast reader, but this book was so boring and such a painstakingly slow read, I stopped after a week and just a third of the way through.

If you're expecting a book about running, this is not it. As an avid runner, it's easy to see the author knows nothing about running or training for a marathon, as the main character in the book is doing. But running is barely mentioned anyway.

The book is so light and fluffy and unrealistic- lots of talk of "ghosts" and reading peoples mind. The characters dialogue is also very unrealistic- no one speaks like that in real life. Especially the exchanges between the main character and her husband- so cheesy!

On top of all that, I caught so many grammatical and spelling errors in this book. How did it get published? I didn't bother to finish reading because there are so many other well written books out there, I didn't want to waste my time, like I had wasted my money.

title: Very disappointing results that take FOREVER
text:
I have had this book for over a year now. I've tried a few of the recipes several times. I am not a novice bread baker, but no expert, so if a recipe from a well-rated cookbook doesn't turn out right, I assume I've done something wrong. I've been baking bread from scratch for years, I use only King Arthur Flours and good quality fresh yeast. I've had wonderful success with Artisan Bread in 5 Minutes A Day, and traditional recipes that require kneading.

I was inspired to try the Pot Boule recipe one more time after receiving an enameled cast iron dutch oven for my birthday. I've tried this recipe 3 times previously, using a different pot each time, assuming that's where I was running into trouble. But now that I had the "ideal" (according to the book) cooking vessel, I figured success for sure. Sadly, 37 hours after first mixing wet with dry, I'm left with a gooey, doughy, burnt edge mess of a loaf - cooked well beyond the roughly 90 minutes recommended in the hopes of reaching the 209-212 internal temperature reading that's recommended in the recipe.

I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone.

title: Story is over-convoluted but it's a decent early Rebus book
text:
A young junkie named Ronnie McGrath is found dead in an Edinburgh squat - positioned like Christ on the cross - with candles beside him and what looks like satanic symbols on the wall. Ronnie's girlfriend, Tracy, tells Detective Inspector John Rebus that Ronnie was distraught before he died, and repeatedly cried "hide, hide." At first it looks like Ronnie overdosed, but Rebus learns that Ronnie's dope was tainted with rat poison.

Because Rebus is involved in a drug case his boss, Superintendent Watson, invites the detective to lunch with a few Edinburgh bigwigs who are involved with an anti-drug campaign. Rebus seems to be of interest to these rich, successful men, who invite him to a classy party and give him an 'honorary membership' in a gambling club.

Meanwhile, Tracy reports that she's being followed, and Rebus notices that he's being followed as well. It's clear that someone is interested in Rebus's investigation, and he has to find out why. To assist with his inquiries, Rebus reaches out to Sergeant Brian Holmes - the cop least likely to complain about Rebus's numerous demands.

It turns out that Ronnie was a threat to some people; Tracy knows more than she's telling; and Edinburgh's upper crust citizens have dark secrets. Some side plots in the story involve illegal dog fights, a gay character, and Rebus's ex-lover - Gillian Templer - who has a new radio DJ boyfriend. Rebus pines for Gillian and wants her back.

The book gets over-convoluted and some plot points don't make sense. Still, Rebus has good intuition and identifies the criminals in the end.

This is an early book in the Rebus series and he's kind of 'Rebus light.' That is - though he's demanding - Rebus isn't the difficult, pushy, irascible, alcoholic, boss-hating man he becomes in later books.

This is a pretty good story, recommended to mystery readers - especially Rebus fans.

He talked about how similar Churchill and Reagan was and then points out how different they were.
He talked about how similar, not on the surface, the two men were, but takes a chapter to talk about the surface similarities.
He has obvious knowledge about the two men, and maybe there were massive similarities but he failed to make the connection in my opinion.
Churchill wrote his own speeches. Reagan wrote some of his speeches and others were written for him that he edited. Not a similarity in my book. Any public speaker will tell you that when a speech is written for you, that you will need to review, practice and edit it.
Sorry. No joy here.

title: Wading through this.
text: Much verbiage before getting to Library of Congress.

title: Another Disappointing Piece of Representation
text:
The following are the thoughts of my little sister who is autistic:
As an autistic girl of color, My Cousin Lili was truly a missed opportunity. If Lili was autistic, why didn’t they say so in the book? Kids will naturally ask questions about why characters do things the way they do. If these questions aren’t answered, it’ll boil down to “What’s wrong with Lili?”

There’s nothing wrong with Lili humming sometimes, there’s nothing wrong with her twirling and twirling. If these things aren’t explained in the book, it will cause problems. The only good thing about this book was that they added a scripture in the end of the book. That’s it. Overall, My Cousin Lili was a huge disappointment. We didn’t learn much about autism or sensory issues, and anxieties were not mentioned at all! And Lili’s difficulties with socializing were only implied. There are many more books about autism that have more educational value, My Cousin Lili is not one of them.

title: Everything a good romance needs
text:
My Thoughts:

Gimme all the romances please! No, seriously, somebody do this. So, yeah, I went on a requesting spree on NetGalley since my first historical romance was a hit for me. I just couldn't help myself. While this one wasn't exactly the same, it still has its sweetness to it.

It took awhile for us to get there with Olivia and Alastair, but it was compelling. I kept reading the new interactions between them, seeing the little changes taking place, drawing them inevitably closer. Olivia's tenacity was key in the development of it. She drew him in and he couldn't resist. It was impossible not to love her... and then eventually him.

Fool Me Twice has everything a good romance needs. The banter, the precious banter, of Olivia and Alastair woven throughout the story. I would definitely say Meredith Duran is worth picking up off the shelf and giving a shot.

My Rating: Pretty good

title: Are You Kidding Me?
text: You know that commercial with the scared teenagers and the smart one who says “Why don’t we go to the running car?” And they dismiss it, saying “no, let’s hide in the garage with all the chainsaws.” That is this book. One unbelievably dumb decision after another. These people are supposed to be clever, but they are merely puppets for a potentially good plot that is ruined by all the idiots, including the main character, who repeatedly choose the chainsaw-laden garage. From early on, I found myself yelling at the book. I finished it, but only for the sake of the plot. No more of this series for me.

title: More digression than meat
text:
About 80% digression, 20% (if that) actual writing on the history of life. I am a layperson, but I honestly could not tell you what, if anything, I learned about early life from this book. Fortey seems far more preoccupied with the trappings of being a scientist than he is with the science itself.

Buy this book if you want to know about the quality of the eggs served at Fortey's favorite bed and breakfast, "...the perfect bed and breakfast in a Tudor house with flag floors and improbable staircases. [The] breakfast was neither too much nor too little, the egg yolks were soft and the whites were cooked, the toast warm and cut into triangles on which to spread thick, home-made marmalade, and pots of tea arrived unbidden." (ACTUAL QUOTE from page 143 of Fortey hitting peak digression in a chapter on early terrestrial plant life.)

I can not understand how this book came to be known as such a touchstone on the topic.

text: Politics has no place in this book in the way this author users them..In my opinion the authors politely views are quite naive and not well researched at all. It appears as though a Democratic view is being favored and pushed at readers right from the beginning. It's too bad the author could not have researched this topic well stuck to it better and written more in depth about it as it is an important one. For instance did you know that a victim of narcissistic abuse may not ever but may take years in one instance I know of six years...before realizing cognitive dissonance? It's true. That bears noting and should be elaborated upon among other things. If I were well I'd write much more but I'm not well at all. Don't waste your money on this book but please don't be dissuaded...do your research...ask a psychologist...Dr or other health professional for referrals and do continue reading about this important subject.

title: Too Vague.....Seemed Like Stitched Together Novellas
text: The first book by Piers Anthony I have ever read was "On a Pale Horse" and I thought it was quite fun. So I picked up the 2nd book in the Incarnations series "Bearing an Hourglass". After just finishing this book today, I am not sure if I want to continue onto the next story. The book starts off strong with Norton's agreeing to help out a Ghost Marriage, and finding love, but as soon as he takes over the office of Time.....well the story goes downhill. I didn't think the explanation of what Time's duties were was done very well, so we are not sure what Norton is supposed to do on a daily basis. The journey's Satan sends Norton on at the beginning have the feel of short stories that have been meshed into a larger story, but that don't really belong. Instead of one long coherant tale like "On a Pale Horse", we have to follow Norton through a couple trivial "adventures" that seem like so much filler. To top it off, the part of the novel titled "Drawkcab", just gets downright annoying. I will give book 3 a shot, but if it doesn't put the series back on track, I'm giving up on it.

title: A Novelization, Not the Other Way Around!
text:
I am in no position to comment on the book because I have not read it. What I HAVE read, on numerous occasions, is the fabulous screenplay by Mike Rich on which it's based.

That's right. The book is based on a movie that was created from an original screenplay!

While I realize that most screenwriters are unknown to the general public, it seems wrong and unfair that people might believe that the novel they are reading is the source material for the adapted movie that they love. While that may be the standard chronology in most cases (of adaptation), there are exceptions to the rule, and this is one of them!

FINDING FORRESTER began its life as a winning entry in the esteemed Nicholl's Fellowship screenwriting competition. Only after it became a successful film directed by Gus van Sandt was it turned into a novel. If you want to know more about how that process works, try reading the original screenplay and see how it served as the blueprint for what followed.

The novel may be great in its own right. But those ideas you so adore -- the vast majority, no doubt -- were conceived in the heart and mind of a hard-working screenwriter, difficult as that might be for some people to believe.

Mike Rich is a tremendous writer with compassion, wit and soul. Try watching The Rookie sometime, another screenplay he wrote that became a popular and beloved movie starring Dennis Quaid. Or the upcoming (at this time) Secretariat, which I can only imagine will be awesome too.

This all may seem a trivial distinction to you. Unless you happen to be a screenwriter...

title: Very Poor - Big Disappointment
text: I am an avid knitter and although I found her first book to be entertaining, this follow-up was very disappointing!  The plot was so shallow and ill-thought that it was not balanced off by the yarn and knitting descriptions and scenes.  I was really sorry that I had wasted my time reading it when I could have been knitting instead!

title: slow-moving tales that do not develop
text: "A Price to Pay" by Alex Capus is a novel of three lives that intersect at a certain point and place in time.  The characters are interesting, as is the period in which they live, but they do not seem to develop.  Each tale seems to go nowhere, and what seems like a wonderful idea for a novel at the beginning never develops its promise.

title: not up to snuff
text: This is not a book about a brainship, it is a sequel to a brain space station book.  While it was a little disappointing not to be about a  brainship, it had great potential.  In fact, it was really good until the  end where it seems as if they suddenly realized they had to meet a deadline  and quick wrote the last 10 pages, which of course made no sense.  Bad  endings are bad.  It could have been a stellar book.

title: As Jamie would say....
text:
Jamie Fraser would probably comment: "If ye havna anything worth saying, then tis wiser to be keeping your mouth shut, eh?"
And this goes for writing, too, Diana...THESE BOOKS DON'T HAVE TO BE 900 PAGES LONG, REALLY, THEY DON'T. 300 good pages would be much better!

If I wanted to read a Treatise on Life in the Pre-Revolutionary War American Colonies, I would get a book on history. We don't read adventure/love stories for the boring details of life. Granted, some are required, but give us a break, please, on the medical problems...Not nearly enough plot, either.

Having just found this series, I loved the first three books, no, make that four. But being able to read them fairly closely and in order, I have to say that the quality has gone waaaay down. I'm not even sure that I want to read the last one, especially after reading the reviews.

It's sad when an author can take you from "I can't wait to see what happens to my beloved characters!" to "who really cares, it's just too boring".

Normally, I'm a very positive person. But it's very hard to find something positive to say about how this potentially wonderful story has taken a turn for the mediocre.

title: A Bit Involved, Even for a Heavy Reader, But Good Story
text:
I love a novel that I can sink into and fall in love with the characters...and a trilogy? A dream.

This novel was very involved, detailed and somewhat historical...but I will say that I really loved the first half of this book a lot more than I loved it towards the end. I feel like Harkness didn't know how to end it and then just kept writing and writing, adding more and more detail until she realized that she had two more sequels to write.

I do recommend this book to friends who likes the witches and vampire genre, and I did love this book, even looking forward to the second book. However, as the book approached, I realized that I didn't really want to jump back into the story of these two characters and maybe it's not as great as I thought.

The historical references are a little bit too much, but the character build up is very good. This is the type of book that you like really based on personal preference and not too much regarding the story.

Try it and then you will know if you love or hate it, it's worth the try.

title: STRANGE
text:
The best way to describe this book is "STRANGE". I never really understood it, I guess. The circus is a magic circus, one that isn't really there and yet you can see it in your mind. The author did a great job of describing the tents, the acts, and the smells but the characters were shallow leaving no connection between them and the reader. The last 100 pages are the best of the book but they still leave you asking "huh"?

I have read that we only use 20% of our brain capacity, so conceptually I'm wondering if the author was thinking that these things could be possible if we used more of our brains than we do. I also wonder if this book is enjoyed by a much younger generation. I guess I'll find out during our discussion at book club. As for me, I wouldn't recommend.

title: Short and Odd Writing Style
text:
The author chose a very different writing style talking in third person but writing like the corrupt bartender (we never find out his name) is telling the story. The bartender meets up with nothing but losers at his bar and when he isn't drunk himself, he is taking undesirable women into the storage room. The writing style was a little difficult for me and it was like a drug addict explaining their drug trip. There were some interesting parts though. One patron is threatened with death at a specific date and the bar patrons decide to protect him and have a party at his apartment on the day he is supposed to die. The party ends up being an orgy with hookers and other wildness.

If you like fast and wild tales you will probably like this book. I couldn't give it more than three stars because it is just not my thing.

title: Disappointing historical fiction read
text:
I could not get into any type of good reading groove with this one. The beginning was confusing to the point in which I had to read the publisher's synopsis to figure out what was even going on. Then a little bit of the backstory is introduced about the two sisters and I start getting my hopes up. But that was short lived and I just never felt fully invested in the characters or the story. I think this is a case of a book just not being the right fit for me.

The story takes place in 1912 and from my understanding of the Author's Note this book is a work of fiction but the writer did draw some inspiration from real life events and people. This book can be placed in the historical fiction genre but much of it is the product of the author's creativity and imagination. Thea and Kay are half-sisters and there is a bit of an age gap between the two of them. After their father died, Thea put her plans of marriage on hold to relocate and raise her younger sister. Now ten years later, Thea is recently married to the captain of the Morning Light ship. The newlyweds and Kay set off for a lengthy voyage.

I felt like I was able to better understand after reading the Author's Note what she was going for in the book and I appreciate the attempt to bring something different to the historical fiction genre. Unfortunately I had a hard time with the actual execution and had a bit of a choppy reading experience. Early on I felt like it was setup for me to care about the two sisters, but ultimately I just didn't, especially in regards to Kay.

Judging by some of the other early reviews, either the story hits home with you or it is a complete miss. While I had problems with the story, it certainly doesn't mean other readers won't enjoy it.

Thank you to Netgalley and W. W. Norton Company for providing me with an advance digital copy in exchange for an honest review!

title: PHANTOM LOVER
text:
I absolutely/positively loved Tess Gerritsen's book entitled "Playing With Fire". It's a literary masterpiece. It's hard to believe that this novel was written by the same person.

Ava rents a house in Maine for the summer with a dazzling view of the ocean. She's hoping it's a serene place to write & heal. She's writing a book about traditional New England cooking. She's exploring the cuisine of seafaring families. She has a long list of recipes she wants to test.

The house was built by Captain Brodie who made his fortune as a ship master. The house is over a hundred fifty years old. This is her private hideaway where she hopes to make peace with herself.

She's avoiding emails & phone calls from her sister, the person she loves the most & never meant to hurt. Alcohol is her anesthetic. Only by drinking herself into a stupor every night, is she able to fall asleep. How easily one drink becomes two, then three, then four. This is how it all went wrong in the first place. A few too many glasses of champagne on a snowy New Year's Eve. She fled Boston because she cannot face up to the past. She's isolated herself in a lonely house with a badly behaved cat as her only companion.

In her bedroom, she's visited by the ghost of Captain Jeremiah Brodie who is preceded by the scent of the ocean. He speaks to her. He's hungry for the taste of a woman, as hungry as she is for the taste of a man. A long-dead man makes love to her. Their first rendezvous is about pleasure. Their second, is about pain.

Somehow, he has looked into her soul & has seen her guilt and her shame. He watches her. Is the house haunted? Does the ghost of Jeremiah Brodie still linger in the house? Or is she delusional? Is it possible that he's nothing more than a fantasy born of far too many bottles of booze?

title: Tiresome and annoying

title: Where Total Quality Management May Have Started
text:
I enjoyed this book from the standpoint of learning how projects such as Disneyworld test all of the construction processes to ensure safety. I read this just as the Israel ballroom where a wedding dance was being held collapsed this weekend and was startled to see the first people they arrested (immediately!) were the contractor and chief engineer!
The author's assertion that Walt Disney would have nothing but the best, at any cost of time and money, shows why Disneyworld was selected by Tom Peters for his work on "In Search of Excellence". I.E., excellence starts at the bottom and trickles up....P>As the author states in the beginning, this was just "a little book" about his experiences with the project, and I found it to deliver that story in an unassuming manner. I loved the working man anecdotes!

title: Nice small-town setting, noncredible protagonist and denouement
text:
Samuel Craddock, chief of police in Jarrett Creek, Texas, is missing the wonderful baked goods his neighbor Loretta Singletary often brings over to delight his taste buds, but he becomes very alarmed when her other friends reports she has disappeared. His concern grows when he discovers she has been using an online dating site to meet men, and a full-scale investigation by Craddock and his deputy Maria Trevino ensues. Then another middle-aged woman disappears in a neighboring town under similar circumstances. With all of this going on, Craddock does NOT need the distraction of trying to referee a challenge to the local Catholic church’s control of the popular annual goat rodeo by the new Baptist minister.
After the reader is introduced to the issues the chief faces, the book turns into a fairly straightforward police procedural made more interesting by the glimpses of small-town life and characters. I was almost immediately put off, though, by the way the character of Craddock was portrayed. He comes across as quite the country bumpkin, who has almost no idea what online dating is about and does not even know enough to Google to find information. He is not a Millennial, by any means, but he was police chief previously and then a successful businessman in the oil field before returning to Jarrett Creek. It is not believable to me that he would not have more expertise with computers than is described. To strain credibility further, this same man then sits down at Loretta’s computer and looks at the history of her searches before she disappeared. Where did that more sophisticated expertise come from? He is not much more believable when it comes to police procedure. When he comes out of his house and sees that someone has apparently broken into Loretta’s house, he runs to the house without apparently taking his gun. And when the police from a neighboring town tell him another woman has disappeared, he does not even think to ask the woman’s name (nor does the other police officer think to give it to him).
After this it was not surprising to me that the denouement came from left field and had some big unexplained aspects to it, including just how Loretta was captured and successfully held captive.
I had read the first book in this series and enjoyed the atmosphere of the small Texas town. It was easy to pick up the context---it was no surprise that Samuel Craddock is now chief of police, and I think this is a series that readers need not read in order. If you enjoy small-town atmosphere and are not too picky about flaws in plot or character, you might like to visit the folks of Jarrett Creek, Texas. Readers who find it more difficult to suspend disbelief might want to give it a pass.

It certainly covers the dramatic period when the Atlantic was America’s main lifeline to the world.

title: WHERE'S MY COW? by Terry Pratchett and Melvyn Grant
text:
Where's My Cow? is a tie-in with Pratchett's Discworld novel Thud!. It is ostensibly a children's book, although the target audience is quite obviously Discworld fans of all ages. This is perfectly in keeping with the burgeoning number of Discworld-related books that have been cranked out lately.

This is not, as might be expected, the version that appears in that book. Instead, Where's My Cow? is about Sam Vimes reading Where's My Cow? to his son, just as he did in Thud!. Mild silliness ensues. The problem is that there isn't really anything here that wasn't also in Thud!.

There have been a lot of complaints about Melvyn Grant's illustrations, mostly about his depiction of Vimes. Well, that's artistic expression for you. There's nothing terrible about the illustrations, even if they aren't great.

Where's My Cow? is really for serious Discworld fans only, most of whom will only be inclined to read it once. If you aren't a Discworld fan, you won't get it.

TAKE IT OR LEAVE IT

title: The writing isn’t bad but the message is problematic.
text:
What I Didn’t Like:
-Kate. I wanted to like her and relate to her struggle. Afterall, I’m a working Mom. Instead, I hated her whiny attitude and the way she treated her husband. I didn’t suddenly relate to her and think this book spoke to me, I just wanted to walk away from her.
-Not all husbands are utter trash, incapable of even getting themselves dressed in the morning. I hate the arguments that start with “not all …” but, seriously, I felt like I needed to say that after reading this book. The author paints all men as complete garbage who can’t do anything right and absolutely never change a diaper. It’s a terrible way to feel about the opposite sex and not at all a message I agree with.
-Balance is possible. I went into this book hoping to read something about the balance between working and mothering. I was hoping to relate to a character who was trying to do it all but learning that balance. I was hoping to laugh a little. Instead we had Kate, who obviously wasn’t balancing well and didn’t seem to care or learn the message. I wanted better.

What I Did Like:
-The harmless flirting through email. I liked that angle, I liked the way it was handled.
-The places where Kate confronts women in the workplace of a big company like this and how they have to handle themselves were well done.
-That Bridget Jones style sarcastic, funny voice. I have a feeling that’s what carried this book so far up the charts.

Who Should Read This One:
-If you’re of the opinion that men need to be coddled and mothered and that women should do everything in their household, you may like this one.

My Rating: 2 stars.

title: I wasn't a huge fan of this book. The ...
text: I wasn't a huge fan of this book. The artwork was a collage style that to me seemed rather distracting. I appreciate that there are a lot of different styles of art and we should expose kids to variety but I was hoping for something a little more educational and functional and less frilly and artsy.

title: Negative Message to Kids
text: I don't care for the message in this Pout Pout book. The fish says to himself several times that he "is stupid," "can't do it," and other negative self-talk. At the end of the book the teacher fish corrects this and says "you are smart," and "you can do it," but you have to get through the entire book to get to that point. I'm concerned that toddlers/young children won't internalize the ending as much as they do they negative self-messages throughout the majority of the book. In addition, placing the focus on whether one is "smart" enough in an academic setting is a poor way to represent school success to children. Kids don't need to hear that they are "smart" they need to hear that they are hard-workers, and that they tried hard and didn't give up despite challenges. These are the qualities that make a successful student, not "smarts," some undefinable quality that guarantees success to those who have it, and dooms those who don't (by the child's estimation or the parent/teacher's) to school failure.

title: Did Not Finish
text:
I see by glancing at some other reviews that this novel "picks up" later in the book. For those of you who can make it that far, that's good news. Place me among the reviewers who found the opening confusing and relatively flat. I made it for about a 100 pages and hit my limit.

I rarely understand the need to jump back and forth over time. To what end? I don't mind being challenged to keep track of a narrative thread, but it has to be done for good reason. It takes a special book and a special reason in the hands of a very competent author to pull this off and pull it off well. Even in those cases if I were the editor I would ask, "why are you choosing to tell the story out of order?"

The additional challenge for Kushner was to build points of view through the eyes of two young children. The challenge, as always with young adults or old children, is choosing a vocabulary and awareness that truly matches that perspective. It would be helpful if it were an adult recalling what he or she thought as a young teenager, for instance, but Kushner never suggests that it's anything but the youngster's point of view. Coupled with relatively flat and dispassionate writing, the result is a challenging narrative to swallow. A sample: "Maybe we should have seen it coming. It takes a while to put thing together. You can't always do it while it's happening to you. A week before the fire started, the rebels closed down the main highway east to Las Tunas. That meant they had control of Oriente, so much of which was owned by Americans. Us, and the American government, who ran the Nicaro nickel mine. Batista was persona non grata with the Cubans and we were caught in the middle. Fidel and Raul, these were local boys, and I think Daddy was hoping he could reason with them. But after the embargo on U.S. sales of military planes to Cuba, that was in March of '57, Batista put pressure on Daddy to convince John Foster Dulles--Mr. Dulles was a friend of Daddy's and a stockholder and his brother Allen was on the company's board--to find a loophole to get a sale of bombers through."

I know kids are smart and put lots of information together (I've got two teenagers), but this kind of info dump back-story being told by a young person didn't connect. I wasn't sold.

The writing is detailed and the atmosphere is certainly evocative of Cuba, although I've never been there, but I wish the character believability and the plot matched the setting.

title: Thoughts and opinions on Winston Churchill
text: Not a true biography but more than just a compilation of essays concerning Churchill's life and times, the author provides us with a 300+ page synopsis/chronology with a sprinkling of his thoughts, insights and conclusions. I found nothing new or "earth-shattering" here. On the other hand it makes a nice supplement, (i.e. much like Meachem's book on FDR and Churchill), to biographys/books I have read. If you are looking for a full-fledged bio start elsewhere, (Manchester or Gilbert), and if your interest is piqued as mine was, come back to this one.

title: Girl Should Get Off the Train

title: Poorly written.
text: This is a required book for one of my courses. I wish I had another option. The writer does not write very clearly in my opinion. It's not just the context, it's the style of writing that just makes things so unclear. I'm a straight A student yet still struggling to read through the text.

title: Random action, unlikeable characters, never gets to the point...
text:
The biggest fault I had with this book was that it took almost the entire 500+ pages to truly (I think) start the story. The rest is about the meanderings (well ok, battle filled meanderings) of characters from a wide variety of areas. Probably the best comparison I can make is with "Fellowship of the Ring" by Tolkien. Both books involve a quest that is a major turning point in the characters' lives and the world (I assume so anyhow for "The First Law" series, not having read the latter two books). But whereas "The Fellowship of the Ring" places the start of the quest relatively early but after a buildup which makes the necessity and gravity of the quest apparent, "The Blade Itself" waits til the end and the quest appears to come out of nowhere with no indication as to why it's important.

The rest of the book comes across as a weak "Song of Fire and Ice" clone, with sections focusing on different characters from different political entities but none of these sections really grabbed me or made me care about what might happen to the characters. One is a bitter, crippled torturer. One is a pampered, spoiled, lovesick noble. One is a barbarian well known for his abilities in battle (I'll admit, this character did provide a rather well done plot twist at one point). One is a wizard who has an ulterior motive. Etc... The different political factions fight against each other, but I rarely got a sense as to why certain things were done. Battle scenes were thrown in pretty much at any opportunity. One of the characters is training for a contest, and those scenes seem nothing more than some medieval version of "Rocky".

The upshot is that for me, this novel was a slow read, punctuated by somewhat random (if reasonably well written) battle sequences, peopled by characters I couldn't empathize with, in a world with somewhat simplistic connections between the different factions, and left me just as confused as to where things were going at the end than at the beginning.

To be clear, I don't need to be hand-held when reading. I don't mind a bit of mystery, or surprising changes of direction. But for a change of direction to be surprising, there has to have been another solid seeming direction beforehand, and I never got this impression when reading.

I also didn't feel like I'd wasted my time after reading it, but it failed at its task of getting me interested enough to buy the next novel.

title: High-pitched intensity!
text: Interesting, imaginative, poetic, but unrealistic. Ruby caves in the Sunderbans?  Give me a break! The plot line imitates Mrs. Henry Wood's East Lynne where the wife reappears disguised and becomes nanny to the family.  Poetic prose is alright in small doses but extravagance can cloy. Sudha's  stories are unrealistic, even bizarre, and there is little to distinguish  the characters' dialogue.  They all talk the same way.  In fact, do people  actually speak in such long poetic paragraphs?  The author should beware  of a characteristic in contemporary Indian women writers that smacks of  exaggeration: larger-than-life women, weak/imperfect men.  It looks like  feminism is finding its balance in the West, but Indian women writers have  just discovered it.

title: DOA
text: While the details about the ballet are interesting, the plot shuffles along. Nothing much happens and it takes pages upon pages to realize that not much is going to happen. It's more a book about the insides of a ballet company than a murder mystery. The characters are not well drawn out and the dialogues feel stilted. If you are interested in ballet, there are better books. If you are looking for a good mystery, skip this one.

title: More suited for web analysts' managers
text:
This is a fast reading book about how to be an effective web analyst at a large company that can afford such. The author writes that the web analyst needs to analyze web stats with respect to company's goals, and then to present to management and other company staff, goal-oriented action steps. With color illustrations, so very pleasant fast reading.

Not really sure this book's worth the money though. Though it talks about a web analyst job, its simplistic message is that a job (any job--e.g. web analyst) needs to be seen in relationship to the company's goals and its other employees. So, the book is basically a Business 101 Career Guide--to understand what one's job in a company really is.

My opinion is that this book is more appropriate for the web analyst's manager--so that the manager understands what the web analyst is suppose to be doing. It's too basic for a web analyst careerist.

title: ... YA literature and this was by far my least favorite book. It was hard for me to get ...
text: I read this for a college class on teaching YA literature and this was by far my least favorite book. It was hard for me to get through.

title: Curiosity-Inducing
text:
THREE QUICK POINTS
* Point 1: A bit chilling. At least, the beginning was. What would you do if some creepy dark creature offered to eat your fears?

* Point 2: Mmmm, cheesy cliché filling. The entire middle section of the book is devoted more to shock value than fear factor.

* Point 3: The end is curiosity inducing. If I didn't know better, I'd say I'd been devoured because I'm anxious to read the next installment.

SHORT SYNOPSIS
When her mother ups and leaves, Regina must help take care of her younger brother Henry while their father runs his construction business. Reggie, along with her best friend Aaron, is an avid reader and horror fan. One of her rituals with Henry is to read him scary bedtime stories, the most recent of which is from the journal of a seemingly crazy woman where she talks about frightening creatures called Vours. On a lark, Reggie and Aaron decide they're going to summon a Vour. Of course, they don't really expect anything to happen, but something does--to Henry--and it's up to them to solve the mystery and save Reggie's little brother.

MY THOUGHTS
Some parts were good, and some parts were lame, but something must have been done right because I have a burning desire to read the next book.

The story unfolded well; the process of Henry's devouring was downright chilling (that makes up the first quarter of the book). I was hoping the momentum would continue, but it petered out and the story became something straight out of a B horror movie.

Although Henry is acting differently (like people and pets dropping dead in his presence), neither Reggie nor Aaron wonder whether he's possessed until well after any clear thinking person would have. But I was willing to forgive that.

What I had difficulty forgiving was the gore-for-scare effect filling out the story, some of the dialogue was pure cheesy cliché, and character development left much to be desired.

Call me jaded, but anyone who's ever watched more than a few classic horror movies would see right through it--in fact, I laughed a couple times. I truly wish it had more of the creepy ominous psychologically frightening effect displayed in the beginning (that section should not be read at night or in the dark), but if wishes were pennies, I'd be a millionaire.

What has my panties in a bunch, though, is the fact that I really, really want to read the next book. The Devouring ended at the beginning of a bigger mystery. It's not to say that The Devouring wasn't a full story in and of itself--it was, thank goodness--but the story left me wondering: Who is Eben really? What are the Vours? And what is their ultimate plot? (Which is what a good series style book ought to do.)

That's why this book was so difficult to rate. On one hand, a chunk of the story I would consider lame in the horror department, relying more on clichéd gore than suspenseful gore, but on the other hand, it did an amazing job of painting a larger story, piquing curiosity, and it *was* a fun read. So I'll just say this: if you're a fan of horror and have read/watched many horror novels/movies, you won't find too many surprises here, but the mystery of the Vours is great.

title: Nothing Happens
text:
Sorry for the cheap choice of headline but it's true. Catch 22 is a blast, and Kurt Vonnegut lauded it so I was all in I love just about everything KV. But this thing is long boring mess.
In my opinion, which is worth about a fifty cents i have this hunch that he was trying to emulate Beckett. Beckett's "Three Novels," is a masterpiece but pretty difficult to read. I absolutely love Malloy, but the other two I'm still working on.
I also think Jose Seramago used a similar style in his book The Double, but at least that had a plot and drew you in .
Something Happened seems like it was written by the 17 year old version of his main character. Which is fine but I'm not into YA literature.
