title: 'Unspoken Truth' Review [MINOR SPOILERS]
text:
I've come across more than a few reviews of this book online, and the one gleaming review posted on Amazon at the time of this posting. The reviews have really lauded this book as great, a must-read, wonderful ... but the book I read is anything but. It is horribly dull, contrived and just a step above fan-fiction that you could Google and get online. I've read both [[ASIN:0743464079 Catalyst of Sorrows (Star Trek: The Lost Era, 2360)]] and [[ASIN:0743496930 Burning Dreams (Star Trek)]], both by Margaret Wander Bonanno, and both dealing with unanswered questions from the 'Original Series' era. In brief, 'Unspoken Truth' is supposed to do for the character of Saavik what 'Burning Dreams' did for Captain Pike: give a underused character in Trek lore his/her moment in the spotlight and reveal new and interesting things about them that the tv series and movies left untouched. I was disappointed to say that 'Unspoken Truth' really is a bust and dropped the ball when it comes to doing justice for the character of Saavik. Perhaps it missteps in trying to insert the character into one of the most unoriginal plots one could think of: the heroine is pushed to her limits and is lost emotionally after traumatizing events and extreme circumstances (Star Trek: Wrath of Khan, Search for Spock and The Voyage Home). As a result, she reflects on her past and is recruited by the 'enemy' to ruin her mentor, Sarek's, career. Now, 'Burning Dreams' and 'Catalyst of Sorrows' both worked well because their plots didn't involve an outcome we were too sure about. We all know from other Trek movies, shows and books that Sarek lived a long life and his career never suffered a setback as this book tries to hint at. Thus, the reader is treated to a long, drawn out novel that at the end feels very predictable, contrived and horribly executed.

The Good: The only good I have to say about this novel is that I enjoyed the scenes that filled-in between the movies. We're treated to what could be considered 'cut' or bonus scenes from Star Trek: The Search for Spock and Star Trek: The Voyage Home. Kirk worrying about Spock returning to his old self after the events of Star Trek: The Search for Spock and Voyage Home was actually entertaining, as was McCoy's few appearances. Another character that seemed to get a lot of great scenes was Amanda, who is seen and portrayed more as a mother in this novel than as a wife as she usually is in most novels. Beyond these two areas, there's not much to praise.

The Bad: Where to begin. I feel 'Unspoken Truth' is guilty of really confusing and giving the character of Saavik a makeover when none was necessary. Compared to what was shown in the movies and what was written about Saavik in other novels, this one turns her into a rebellious teen with unchecked emotional problems, lacking common sense and devoid of logic. Basically, gone is the Saavik of the movies and in her place is a character from some 1980s brat pack movie. Every sentence that Saavik thinks or says seems to end with an exclamation point as if she is forever mad or on edge. This book (to my knowledge) rewrites her character's history a bit to make it so that she was found by Spock as a young child, brought home, raised by Sarek and Amanda, mentored by 'big brother' Spock ... and I'm sorry, but the author does nothing to make any of this, or Saavik's relationship with any of the characters, believable. Part of this problem is that there are two plots going on within this book that hardly go together and so both end up being short-changed. The plot described on the back of the book ... sorry to reveal that it doesn't even occur until page 209 at which point it's rushed and pushed through and never fully developed. The majority of the book deals with Saavik seeking a quiet, un-eventful mission following the events of Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home. That's exactly what she gets and what the reader must sit through and endure. The first 200 pages of this novel are for the most part a total bore. Then comes the Romulan plot to recruit Saavik to ruin Sarek's career. It's contrived, predictable and meanders without any true focus. A couple of pages in, you're able to guess the outcome at every twist and turn. Annoyingly, 'unspoken truth' appears in the dialogue various times but I must say by the end, I have no idea what the author was trying to refer to or get at with the title. The end of the novel ends with dialogue that made this feel like 'The Little Mermaid' made-over for Star Trek: Father-figure Sarek realizes he can't force Vulcan tradition on his daughter Saavik and that he and Amanda have raised her to the best of their ability and must let her go off into the vast universe on her own. Seriously.

Let me not forget to mention that Saavik also finds a new love in this novel and behaves like a promiscuous teenager in heat, at once jumping into bed and a complicated relationship with her new guy ... even after pages of her agonizing over how mating with Spock in Star Trek: The Search for Spock was unwise and complicated her life and brought her much grief and personal shame. So, again, what in the world? I don't understand why so many readers are jumping for joy over this book when it's nothing more than a harlequin romance novel set in the Star Trek universe. This book is pretty much character assassination for the character of Saavik. It doesn't do anything to make her any more clear, likable or smart/intelligent as she was portrayed in the films and in other books. It was as if someone gave Bonanno free range to do as she pleased with the character(s) (because not even Sarek or Spock feel totally in character). On an entirely different note, was this the absolute best cover Pocket Books could come up with because it seems like a pretty lame cop-out for doing something more representative of the events of the novel. I guess this is supposed to be Vulcan, perhaps Sarek's residence ... whatever the case, it's never explained or linked to the events of the novel. Could they not have, I don't know, put an image of Saavik on the cover since the novel is about her?

Avoid this book. I rarely give out 1 star reviews but this was by far the worst book I've read in a long time. It's dull, the first 200 pages have nothing at all to do with the book's description and even that plot is dull, lacking and poorly written. I expected a lot more from the author who has written some great novels but as said, this book certainly isn't one of them. The author managed to turn one of Trek's most interesting characters into nothing more than a cardboard cut-out from an adolescent novel. The plot does not feel original and is planted in the middle of a time period and dealing with characters whose outcomes we're aware of and thus can easily predict the outcome of the book, making reading this horrible mess of a novel pretty much wasted money and paper. The novel ends with Saavik pretty much where she was when the novel began and looking forward to getting back to duty and returning to the Enterprise if Kirk and crew will have her. Uh, we all saw Star Trek IV: The Final Frontier and the films that followed so yet again, we know the outcome of that event. This novel was, in my opinion, a missed opportunity. I'd rather have been treated to a novel that filled in a piece of Star Trek history that hasn't been covered to death and was unknown to the reader so that reading it would have created more history. Perhaps having focused on Saavik post Original Series movie era, or even before she came into the picture and really explored her alone, not attached to Spock or Sarek, would have improved the novel. Whatever the case, I can't in good conscience recommend this novel to anyone. SKIP IT.

text: So, after having multiple affairs while married to her supposedly wonderful husband and becoming a heroine junky with a guy so hideous that when she becomes pregnant with his baby there is no doubt she will abort- and indeed she does (did she even call the guy?) she goes right back in the sack and does heroine again with this person so horrible that the baby must die.  Hey Cheryl- maybe instead of honoring your mom by ruining your marriage, becoming a junky, sleeping around, and behaving in the most irresponsible, horrible ways possible you could have finished college, got a degree, got a job, honored your marriage vows, paid off the student loans that you took out (instead of whining about having to pay for the loans which you, an adult, took out), and became a contributing member of society.  This book is so awful as to be unbelievable.  If this book is true, the author needs to seek mental health treatment.  I want my money back.  Only buy this book if you want to read the story of a woman so self-indulgent, so egotistical, so lacking morals, and so whiny that you will need to take a shower just to wash off the stench of the authors behavior and go out amongst normal people.  I wonder who told this woman it would be a good idea to write a book which reveals her as an absolute jerk.

title: Talente writer - would like to see more character development
text:
This is my first Colleen Thompson novel. I think that she has a lot of talent.

The story follows Rachel, a photographer who is trying to restart her life after being acquitted for the murder of a former art student who stalked her. That's quite a mouthful, so I'll wait for you to read it again.

Rachel heads home to Texas, where her grandmother, father, and stepmother live. She's understandably brittle, as some people still think she might have committed the murder as well as other heinous acts.

However, she meets Zeke, a man running away from his own past. Can these two people, so beaten down by life, find love? I think you can probably guess the answer to that one.

There were some surprises, which always makes a mystery, well, a mystery. I think that if this had a bit more character development, I would have enjoyed it more. I just couldn't care about the characters as much I wanted to.

Overall, not a bad read and I will probably check out some of her other books.

title: It’s also super fun to Google variations of the sentiment in order ...
text:
The concept of fiction as a lie whose subtext is actually truth has been around for a long, long time. It’s also super fun to Google variations of the sentiment in order to see how many quotes you can find that are variations of the tune:

“Fiction is the lie through which we tell the truth.” –Albert Camus, author-

“Art is a lie that tells the truth.” –Pablo Picasso, painter-

“Fiction reveals truth that reality obscures.” –Ralph Waldo Emerson, poet-

“Truth is stranger than fiction, judgie wudgie.” –Curly, Stooge-

It’s one of those witticisms that’d likely be labeled a cliché if it weren’t so matter-of-factly true for so many people who dabble in fiction. Authors have a tendency to write what they know. That doesn’t necessarily mean that Jo Walton personally knew a bunch of fairies at one point or another in the course of her life, but there is a subtext to her imaginings that are likely pinned on a lived and/or learned experience. Fiction is often an extreme elaboration for something gnawing away at writer. Fahrenheit 451, for example, was about the destruction of books and ideas. It wasn’t that Bradbury was quaking in his boots at the thought of suppressive fascism, as it is often thought, but was a cry in the dark by a man who fiercely loathed television and believed it was a machine that made people much dumber than they ought to be, and kept them from reading.

Also, Jo Walton is the kind of person that will use a word like “axiomatically” in the opening line of her acknowledgements. It’s only fair to allow her the pretension of her claim that the fairies were real. Of course the fairies were real. Any reader worth his or her salt accepts axiomatically the reality of fairies.

But allow me to dial back the harsh nature of my criticisms. Jo Walton claims the reality of fairies for two reasons, 1) because she is selling herself as an author of imaginative whimsy, and it’s a good line to leave off on, and 2) she is really implying the virtues of imagination, which can have as much worth as any old bit of reality.

About half way through the book is a passage about dolls that encapsulates the wonderful, tangible reality of imagination and the banality of the real:

“The problem with Rosebud and her really talking was that our other dolls could pretend talk, and that was better. Our collection of dolls…had epic adventures surviving after nuclear wars or rescuing dragons from evil princesses. Battered old Pippa, with her one arm and her ragged hair…could stand there vowing defiance and revenge against the evil Dog Overlord…and Rosebud couldn’t compete when all she could say was “Let’s play schoo-ul.” (pg. 159-160)

Rosebud the doll is meant to emulate the really real world. Notice, too, that the doll not only represents bland reality, but implores children to “play schoo-ul,” which is far from what most children want to be bothered with.

Reality is for suckers, and that’s definitely something I accept axiomatically.

Now, I know that this review is a bit sarcasm-heavy, but I would be lying if I tried to tell you that it wasn’t beautifully written. I can make that concession, though I cannot claim to be the audience for this particular story. It would not keep me from seeking out other works by this author.

title: What if economists were irrational rather than voters?
text: The American voter don't like capitalism, therefore they are...irrational. Well, first of all, the American people are hardly anticapitalist. Unless you are a fanatical Randian, you can hardly say that the administrations the American people have elected throughout US history have been anticapitalist. But is true that Americans have become more suspicious of unbridled capitalism. They realize that capitalism is very good at creating wealth, but that is also very good at destroying the social networks that have served mankind quite well through evolutionary times. After all, man is a social animal (unless you want to argue, like Margaret Thatcher, that there is no society, just individuals). Same for free trade. It might bring cheaper goods for the consumers, but it also destroys the manufacturing base of the country. The average voter is more intelligent than the economist in realizing there is at least a tradeoff in this; that this is hardly a win win situation. But this is something that extreme free market economists, wedded to a theory, cannot see. So who is irrational here?

title: And I thought I was low maintenance....
text: The only real qualm I had about this novel was that this Anastasia chick wore the same dress and underwear for four days straight and had it laundered once, after the third day. And I thought I was low maintenance.....

title: Ms. Evanovich Please Let Stephanie Grow Up
text: Ten Big Ones is not a bad book.  The reader gets introduced to Ranger's hideout (the Rangeman facility) and his apartment on the 7th floor.  Now THAT is fun because who doesn't want to know more about Ranger!  In this book Ranger still maintains that sultry classiness which makes him desirable (the classiness which he loses in book 17 when he is brought down to Stephanie's low class level).  In this book he remains an enigma.  Which is what makes his character so interesting.  We also get to see a faint glimpse of independence in the Stephanie Plum character.  A tiny bit of feminism that her character is almost always completely lacking.  Unfortunately, just as soon as we glimpse it, the author yanks it away.  Stephanie Plum isn't amusing as much as she is cringe worthy.  Which makes me sad.  I would like for Stephanie Plum to be more of a hero.  I would like her to be deserving of Morelli or Ranger.  Ten Big Ones starts out with the worn out rehash of the "car incident" (with a car always being spray painted, blown up or catching on fire).  The rest of the book is Stephanie making the usual questionable and even stupid decisions, Stephanie and Lula driving all around Trenton, Stephanie's life being threatened and Stephanie having to be rescued, blah blah blah.  The "mystery" factors are always weak and it's the same with book 10.  There is the usual page after endless page of (fattening) food descriptions.  At least in this book the author gets honest and admits the truth about the main character.  Stephanie is asked multiple times if she's pregnant.  Stephanie herself comments on how disgusted she is with her own body. There is nothing sexy about Stephanie Plum. The author asking readers to believe that either Morelli or Ranger would ever look twice at Stephanie as a potential romantic or sexual partner is really pushing the borders of fantasy.  But then again the books in this series ARE fiction.  9/6/11

title: Boring and predictable

title: Disappointing
text: The packaging of this spirit animal deck is gorgeous, but once you get past the glittery silver snakeskin exterior, the deck itself is disappointing. As many have pointed out, the cardstock is of inferior quality. In addition, the illustrations vary widely in quality from card to card. Some animals are rendered thoughtfully and artistically--some look like amateur scribbles. The descriptions of the card meanings are very short and in a hard-to-read font. I returned the deck.

title: Bad Binding Gave Way Completely Before I Could Read A Single Panel.
text: I like the character and enjoyed volume one but can't speak about the content of this volume- as it literally fell to pieces in my hands in a flurry of pages because of shoddy binding before I could read it...not just a few pages- all of them.  I was left holding just the cover- I was going to rearrange the fallen pages and reorder them like flash cards so I could read the story line- but it just wasn't worth the time.  Did not have this problem with other volumes in the series and I've since learned to break in the spine slowly even in soft cover books before I read as a result of this- be they glued or sewed.  Literally every page- on the floor- fluttering to the ground.  Oh Gravity sometimes you're heartless!  Or was the glue more to blame? Anyway no Buffy for me in this volume; just bad binding and ruined unreadable pages.  I don't kn know if anyone else went through this but my book went completely to pieces and it was supposedly new and mint.

title: One Star
text: Chuck Wendig was a bad pick to write Star Wars novels.

title: Descending order of good
text:
When I bought this book, I did so because I like the concept of space marines. I did not know it was a Warhammer40k tie in, and I knew nothing about the game's universe. When I realized what I had bought, I figured I'd give it a shot anyway.

The leading short story is pretty good. It's actually a pretty classic senario of small force fighting off a greater. Quite a bit of it comes off as over the top, like how thirty men fought off hundreds over many hours. Not great, but a good set up for the characters and their basic motivations.

The first book, "Nightbringer", surprised me. The political intrigue around the attempted raising of a sleeping being of ancient powers worked quite well for me. I thought that the characters worked well and the interactions were believable. I was quite pleased, actually. But this is the best of the three books contained in this omnibus.

The second book, "Warriors of Ultamar", was more of a straight "blow everything up and move towards a goal" story. There was some small intrigue and several new characters, but they both seemed flat and stale. One group of minor characters, a selfish street gang, never showed any development at all over the story which begged the question why they were included at all. This is not a horrible book, and the alien menace is quite clever, but it isn't something that would bring me back.

The third book, "Dead Sky, Black Sun", was the same sort of linear tale as the second one, but just nasty. On the "Eye of Terror", an outcast planet of horrors, the author unleashes all the disgust of a bad splatter movie. I felt queasy reading parts of it and the plot didn't help distract from the gore. At times, this book was just a protracted bloodbath of nastiness. The characters became even more flat, right down to the recycled dialog from "Star Wars". It ends with a touch of cliffhanger, one that I will never have resolved as I plan to read no more of these works.

The first book is worth reading, wheather you are interested in the game or not. The second is poor, but definitly for the gamers. And avoid the third. And after reading these, I have no intrest in trying out the game.

title: Stereotyping College Life
text:
This book is about the corruption of a young American girl from Sparta, a remote mountain town in North Carolina, who makes it against all odds to a top university in Pennsylvania ("Dupont"), only to find out that not top-notch education but rather sex, alcohol, drugs and generlly being "cool" are top-most on her fellow students' minds. Tom Wolfe paints a vivid picture of college life on American campuses, or at least that's what he would have us believe, not too successfully in my mind.

I guess Wolfe was out to write the definitive book about college life. And indeed the book is nothing but a long (700+ pages) description of the frivolities of college students. It is full of stereotypical characters: the basketball players who get academic discounts and lead a life (literally) above the rest, the drunken frat boys and the giggly sorority girls, the group of smart nerds who are after the Rhodes scholarship and, above all, the innocent hillybilly who cannot believe it all - Charlotte. Wolfe, in his charcteristic style, does not leave much to the imagination when describing Charlotte's encounter with college life. One of ther first experiences on campus are the sounds produced by a boy defecating loudly in the stalls of the co-ed bathroom (I will spare you the details). Shortly thereafter, Charlotte's room-mate throws her out in the middle of the night so that she can spend time there alone with her boyfriend; thus Charlotte learns what it means to be "sexiled". And so on and so forth.

Despite its weakness in credibility - I refuse to believe this is what life in Ivy League colleges is all about - what saves this book is Wolfe's excellent writing style, captivating the reader and transporting him to a world that although removed from reality seems at the same time very realistic. I read the book while travelling between three continents and it was a faithful companion on the long flights and sleepless nights. As far as pop fiction goes, it's an entertaining read.

One final thought. Wolfe, author of excellent books such as Bonfire of Vanities and A Man in Full, gives thanks in the foreward to the book to his daughters, who apparently let him into the secret lives of college students based on first-hand experiences. If I am Charlotte Simmons faithfully portrays what Wolfe's daughters went through in college, I shudder to think how he reacted, as a father, when hearing their stories.

title: 3 Stars
text:
I liked this book well enough, but I didn’t like it nearly as much as the first two of this series. I’m not sure I can even pinpoint what it was this book was missing.

I’m not sure I liked the FMC that much. On the surface she seems like the kind of female I would adore. She’s badass, she’s a leader, a fighter. She doesn’t let men dictate to her or push her around…so what was it about her that put me off? I’m not sure. She seemed a bit too desperate for sex, even in super inappropriate and unbelievable situations. Maybe it was something about her demeanor? Maybe her character wasn’t fleshed out enough. Where was her backstory? Nothing besides what she does in the present is mentioned.

Maybe it was the ending that put me off. It didn’t feel like we got good enough closure about the murder of her dad. The bad guys didn’t suffer enough, the final fight scene was over too quickly. The ending was too abrupt. I don’t know. Something was missing here.

Maybe what was missing about this book had to do with the men. We don’t know anything about them besides what they show us in the present. They don’t have personalities besides protectiveness and sex. We know nothing about them. They don’t have backstories. I’m curious about them, they seem like they could be interesting people…but we get no answers about them at all.

I don’t know why, but this book missed the mark for me.

- Multiple POV’s
- No MM
- 3 men in harem: demon prince, fallen angel, and gargoyle
- FMC is a gargoyle
- 6/5 steam rating…there was a bit too much sex. Surprising, huh? This was the steamiest of the series so far.
- Slow build harem
- FMC is the Prez of the MC
- triggers: death of parent, deaths of prominent side characters, betrayal, murder, torture (not of h/H), blood/gore
- Fated Mates
- Disabilities: one of her mates is mute
- the timespan of this book is fairly short, takes place over less than two weeks

title: Great idea, poorly executed
text:
Positive: Great idea. A paranormal summer camp - I've never read about anything remotely like that. Pet ferret, also great idea, and the Scottish accent's a wonderful touch.
Negative: difficult to read because poorly written. It's as though the author couldn't decide whether she wanted to write for third grade, sixth grade, or high school. And if you're a Kindle reader, the enormous (truly, enormous) amount of footnotes, which only appear at the end of each chapter, become positively irritating. I'd much rather have read the footnotes as bracketed notes after a sentence or paragraph - or indeed, as part of the main book. Perhaps the author/editor thought it would make for more interesting reading to do it this way, but in these days of ebooks, the way this was set up is really irritating. At least in my case, it annoyed me enough to decide not to buy the next in the series.
I would not call this a "Young Adult Romance" by any stretch of the imagination.

text:

The Con: Shallow Characters & utterly predictable.

That was the reason he was stuck on the planet in the first place and not to prepare for that on his way to there was kind of crazy considering everything else he was preparing for.

I also thought how the MAV hole being repaired by the HAB canvas was a little nutty considering planetary ascent :)

Anyways, okay book, not really entertaining due to its predictability. Plus you knew the character was just goind to survive from the way the logs were written. I also didn't care for the logs that much, looked more forward to the dialogue.

In summary, a disaster story that has been told thousands of times, but what separates it is the science and accuracy of being in that entire foreign environment.

title: Falls Short
text:
I'm just not sure what Dan Fesperman was aiming for in his novel, "The Prisoner of Guantanamo;" a thriller, a character study of GITMO and its prisoners, the watchers and the watched, a comment on moral ambiguity, all the above? Whatever Fesperman was aiming for, it gets lost in the translation, as if written originally in Arabic and translated by someone for whom the language was as difficult as the culture from whence it comes.

I will say that the novel is interesting in its portrayal of GITMO and its environs, interrogators, security personnel, and inmates, but one would be better served by using the Internet to research the prison, its operation, and culture, as long as one does due diligence on the authors and their motives. For example, Gordon Cucullu has written a non-fiction book on GITMO that's very detailed in its description of the place, but quite biased in its treatment of the operation and culture. Joseph Margulies' book covers the establishment of GITMO and its legal precedents and implications. Using the search term on the ProPublica web site will produce numerous stories covering everything from imprisonment at GITMO to trial of GITMO prisoners. The point is, if you're looking for details on GITMO and its prisoners, fiction, even by someone as presumably well-informed as Fesperman, isn't the place to get it.

So, that brings us back to book as a representative of the "thriller" genre. Here too, the book falls short. Fesperman builds up slowly to a denouement that never really materializes in any sensible or even satisfying manner. The buildup is slow enough that what seem extraneous "adventures" (scenes) are interjected in an attempt to maintain reader interest. To some extent they do, only to let the reader down even harder at the conclusion.

It's my belief that Fesperman never really had a final revelation in mind when he started writing the book, and when he finally got to the final chapter and epilogue he, his protagonist, Revere Falk, and the rest of us were left wondering, "What was the point?"

title: A Disservice to Alex Cross
text:
A quote from the book best describes "Cross Country." "It was baffling, it was incomprehensible. Just wrong on so many levels."

The only reason I can think of that MIGHT have inspired James Patterson to write this awful book is that he might recently have become aware of the plight of millions of people in various African countries and thought he could use his popular character, Alex Cross, to shed light on a truly appalling situation.

However, that said, it was a terrible book with a totally unbelievable plot.

For one thing, what city cop goes hunting a killer in a foreign country...and if he finds him, what is he going to do with him? He has zero authority beyond his own city. And should Alex Cross execute him, it goes against all of his principles which we admire so much. It was a lose-lose situation from the get go.

The brutality toward Cross himself was boggling...and silly at the same time, since one day he is stripped of all of his papers, including passport and money, beaten brutally and next thing you know he is dining with friends, only to be captured and beaten again, and be released again. There was no rhyme or reason and the violence was gratuitous, just the sort of thing I hate. I don't mind reading about violence if it seems integral to the part, but not violence to add more violence to an already violent book.

There are so many things wrong with this book. I was very disappointed in this big stumble by Patterson. In apparently trying to write a propaganda piece, he truly did a disservice to Alex Cross. It will be a long while before I pick up another Alex Cross book.

text: I'll preface this review with the statement "I usually am a big fan of Michael Connelly" and then say I found this book to be a "frustrating read". The lead character was engaging and intelligent and the supporting cast of characters was believable in their roles. However, the consistent use of law enforcement abbreviations without prior foundation was frustratingly irritating. It wasn't until several pages of reading after the fact that I figured out what RA meant. I still have no idea what GOA meant. For me, those irritations detracted from my overall enjoyment of the book. Michael Connelly, you wouldn't have done that as a reporter, what made you so lazy as to do that with this novel?

title: Buy only for entertainment only if experienced with Word
text:
An entertaining index-free 110 page book full of errors and mis-statements. Take for example, page 25, talking about the "Work-Context Help Feature": "The following illustration depicts the appearance of a context help window that provides a description of the command." No it won't- there isn't any illustration, just a blank page. Or page 24:
" * Views / * Views... different view choices... , the Lay outage layout view..."
Every page is a treasure. I've learned a lot by trying to figure out what it is the author is actually trying to say. I got this attempting to discover the Outline view is integrated with the other views, if I ever find that I won't trust what the authors says. If you are inexperienced with Word, this book will definitely keep you that way.

title: Pictures at confusing for teaching the alphabet
text:
The choice of words used to depict each letter of the alphabet is downright confusing! For example for "I" the page says "I is for ink, that makes my hands blue" and has a picture of a girl holding her hands up and the hands are blue. The issue I have with this is majority of the picture is of the girl's body. So my toddler looks at the picture and says "girl" or points to the body parts and names the body parts. This book is supposed to help teach each letter- why would they choose ink?! There is nothing distinctive about the coloring to even make you think it is "ink"... In fact I covered the sentence describing the letter and asked 5 people what they thought this was a picture of and what letter they thought it was for. All 5 people said "H for hands" which proves my point that using "ink" for the letter "I" was a poor choice. This happens again for "Q". The sentence chosen to describe "Q" is: "Q is for quiet as the tired puppy sleeps" and it shows a large picture of a dog sleeping. So now my toddler gets to Q and says "dog!" & this is frustrating as I have to teach her that dog is not spelled with a Q. This happens again with "w" described as "W is for wet, when you're splashing around." While this photo shows a boy with bubbles on him, it doesn't even show water! Once again I asked people what they thought this picture could be for and they said either B for Boy or B for bubble. This is very counter-productive for a parent!! We should have books that are helpful for younger toddlers, not confusing!! even the seemingly simpler pictures, P for piglet or D for duckling.. Why not choose pig or duck? I understand that they chose the correct names (it is a baby duck, so they call it duckling), but for the sake of word association just use a picture of an adult duck. A 15 month old isn't going to be able to comprehend duckling vs duck and it only confuses the child! Lastly, they have odd choices for the sensory portion. For K they choose a kitten playing with a ball of yarn. The cut out has access to the yarn for the child to touch. Wouldn't it make more sense to put a cut out to the fur? So the child associates touching soft fur of the kitten for K? Not yarn...?

To the author/publishing company- please change the Q page to Queen. I page to iguana or ice. The W page to walrus. Make teaching the alphabet fun, not frustrating!

title: Not as good as the description makes it sound
text: I keep buying Kate Morton's books and I keep finding them difficult to read and not as satisfying as they promise to be. Actually, I really enjoyed The Forgotten Garden, but I wasn't a huge fan of The House at Riverton or The Distant Hours. I don't know what it is about the writing style or the characters, but these books don't pace well or keep me turning the pages. They all have classic, Gothic English themes that I should love. However, I think they under-deliver a bit. I don't really care about the main characters (fairly one-dimensional), and the plot moves very slowly without any historical detail or interesting plot developments.

More geared towards kids. Cute pictures.

From page one, the story leads to a showdown (even a shoot out) between a desperate priest who faces a villain and his evil henchmen, who try to control a town for their greedy purposes.  I've seen this story a thousand times in old Westerns, and remain unimpressed.

text: I enjoyed the story in this volume, but the art really disappointed me. I expect the characters in Jem and The Holograms to look beautiful, and I honestly felt they looked ugly in this one. I feel bad saying this about someone's art style, but it truly just didn't appeal to me. For an already established comic where fans have come to know a certain style of art, the artist that takes over should try to stay close to the already established art style. By this volume for the story, but don't expect much from the art.

title: Part fascinating, part disheartening
text: I knew little about Cilla Black until I saw a television account of her life and realized she was from Liverpool and rose to fame during the height of Beatlemania. And that’s when I purchased her autobiography Cilla Black: What’s It All About? I was truly fascinated by the “insider” information about the Beatles and the other groups of the time, among them Gerry and the Pacemakers and Billy J. Kramer and the Dakotas. I loved her descriptions of her close friendships with John, Paul, Ringo and George, especially with Ringo who became a very close friend. She signed with the Beatles’s manager Brian Epstein, and her description of him, their friendship, and her devastation at his death were heartening and entertaining. I loved her telling of how she maintained close friendships with her mates from younger years, especially with her childhood friend Pat Davies and Cynthia Lennon, mother of Julian Lennon and first wife of John Lennon. The book is mostly a seemingly heartfelt tribute, rather than a “dish the dirt” memoir. I, not being British nor having lived in England, was surprised that not only did Black achieve the status of the best-selling female vocalist in her country, but also she became a beloved television personality, hosting several long-term shows. So what just is it that turned me off somewhat to this woman? She wants us to believe she is a still a “hometown girl” Liverpudlian at heart, simple and true to her upbringing. That may very well be true. But today the woman is a multi-millionaire, and while many celebrities seem to not flaunt that and live quiet lives, Black is so proud of it that she writes of her estate in England, her villa in Spain, and her apartment in Barbados as if we all have the opportunity to own such (or at least care deeply about her comfort.) Furthermore, she seems to want to refute every little gaff she made in her career as an “I didn’t mean it that way” moment or “the press misunderstood.” She seems intent, in this book, to whitewash every error she has made in her very public life, when perhaps it would have been best to ignore the tarnish on her silver celebrity status, letting it fade into the history that one forgets. And when she, at the end, lest us know she is on a quest for a perfect pink diamond, one that will cost her well over a million dollars, because she deserves a trinket of that magnitude, I felt like there is no way this boastful wealthy woman has any of her humble Liverpudlian qualities still intact. She just wants us to think that, counting on her adoring fans to say, “Well, we love her and want her to be happy.” She doesn’t dwell on her charitable activities, although she does mention them, but I have to wonder how much that excess-of-a-million dollars would buy if it were channeled into food for the hungry rather than a bauble for her finger.

title: Trust-Fund "Gypsies" Gone Wild
text: Wanted to love this book, read through it hoping it wouldn't disappoint, finished the book wishing it was better.  I love the idea of the bohemian luxury adventure life.  The author did excel at highlighting iconic figures that have shaped the gypset image.  However, the people she selected from the present to represent current gypsetters seemed nothing more than spoiled trust-fund babies who like to party.  I was hoping to learn of artists who broke out of middle America and found themselves on an adventure of a lifetime paved by their artistry, bravado and luck.  In the end it just seemed like the book highlighted a lot of rich people who like to do drugs.  Such a disappointment.

title: Don't expect much of this sequel
text:
I enjoyed the first book of this series, but found this sequel lacking. The time jumps between the parallel stories occurred too often and it made for choppy plots. The characters in both story lines were too similar and the frequent time jumps (that often occurred wily nilly in the middle of a chapter) easily caused a bit of confusion for the reader.
This book was also rife with errors both in format and content -- at one point an integral character was called by the wrong last name. Wish I had just stopped with the first book as this was a waste of both time and money.

title: but the story is boring and not worth $6
text: This is advertised as a 'pop-up' book but it isn't.  It is a paperback book with no pop-ups.  It has a paper dinosaur included in the back that you can "pop-out" to a sort of origami dinosaur, but the story is boring and not worth $6.00

title: Not a great book for the test
text:
I took the CISA exam today, so the exam as compared to this book is fresh in my mind.

Overall, I liked the writing style of the book, and the authors did cover much of the CISA domains of knowledge. But that's where the kudos stop.

Book is full of errors, questions are vague or weak (but they are that way on the real exam, too). The book constantly repeated itself on many topics and missed lots of material. It was easy to see that the authors and reviewers did not review each other's work. There was some wrong technical information, especially around the crypto section. Many things the book went over heavily, and repeated through several chapters, were not on the exam (e.g. TCP/IP model, project management, etc.).

Even their review of the TCP/IP model was wrong. The book constantly referred to the five layers of the model, and the model only has 4 layers.

Yes, several of the book's test answers have the incorrect answer choice (as other reviewers have noted), but even worse, often the answer explanation didn't explain the correct answer. Most exam cram type books do poorly on the test questions, and this book was no different.

Overall, I think the book only prepared me for about 1/10th of the questions presented on the CISA exam. I was scoring 85-95% on the book questions and rarely guessing, but on the exam I was guessing a lot more (80% of the time). I probably passed (I do well on most exams and I've got about 50 other certifications), but it would have been nice to have been spoon fed the possible questions better.

But the real CISA exam is very weird, and like a lot of the other crappy security exams, one book will never prepare, so buy and study at least two.

I did not regret buying this book, and I'll lend it to friends. It's a good starter book. It just isn't a good enough test preparer. But I didn't try any of the other books so I can't give a fair comparison or recommend stronger books.

title: First books is really good, the rest...not so much
text:
Kids love the dystopian society books. Divergent is a great read in that genre. It sets the stage for a series of stories that will allow a strong female character to discover and overcome the boundaries enforced by her society. The only thing is...it falls flat after the first novel. It seems that Veronica Roth had a great idea and then started writing and got a little lost on the journey. It didn't seem to follow a true path of changing the society at hand. I know the kids have raved about it but it was disappointing.

By the third novel, I just wanted it to be over. Off track, completely losing me as a reader.

Similar to City of Ember in that you need to "get out" but City of Ember was more concise and better written.

Sorry!

title: Quirky, beautifully drawn large book for early gradeschool aged kids.
text:
3 stars at Amazon means "It's Okay". It's not really a negative review, more of a... "meh"....

And after processing the colorful, imaginative and distinctive artwork and concept of this book, that's the best I can muster. Over time, we'll see if I tick it up to 4 stars, based on any future repeated "read it again" requests from the 5-year-old.

As it is, it's a perplexing book. It is kind of a like a reference book, a handbook of the kinds of "real" ghosts there are in the household, as described by one of them, Toasty the chimney ghost.... as described to a classic white-sheet-with-2-black-holes-for-eyes dragging-a-ball-and-chain ghost at the beginning of the book. This is a fake ghost, according to Toasty.

Families will have differing opinions about how scary any of these ghosts are, and the night time ghost is by far the scariest, although my pre-reading kid enjoyed my alternate reading of that page, skipping the part where it'll creep into your nightmares if you're not careful. Mostly the ghosts are just kind of quirky, and the real enjoyment of the book comes from poring over the lovely images and finding interesting aspects of them. "Oh, look, there's an elephant outside that window!"

The book isn't profoundly conceived enough to convince anyone of an alternate world of ghosts to what we in the west are used to, and there isn't really a story, per se. At the end, I asked my girl which was her favorite ghost or page, and she went back to the beginning and pointed out the sheet-and-2-eyes ghost. "That one", she said. Only 5, and already ruined for alternate ghost worlds!

title: A Pretty Slow Sequel
text:
Lush and striking, hopeful and devastating, We Free the Stars is the masterful conclusion to the Sands of Arawiya duology by New York Times–bestselling author Hafsah Faizal.

I feel like I'm in the minority here but... I sadly didn't love this sequel as much as I thought I would.

Starting with the characters though, who literally carried this duology for me. I absolutely loved all of them. Zafira may be one of my favorite female book characters of all time. She's powerful and inspiring and I just couldn't get enough of her and Nasir.

But I didn't love this book because it was just so slow. And normally I love slow burns! But in this case I wasn't even excited to pick this one up and it took me so long to read because I felt so unmotivated by it. It definitely picks up towards the end but I just felt so blah about the first 2/3 of this one. I'm still happy I read it because overall I though this series was beautiful and Faizal has a gorgeous and poetic writing style, but I was just sad by the lack of excitement in this sequel.

title: Nothing new or original here
text: An easy, quick read that was all too predictable with a plot that I've read in dozens of other "thrillers'". Nothing new original here. Nothing "thrilling" when you have it all figured out one-third of the way through the book. The sex scenes were totally unnecessary and added nothing to the plot or character development. Just OK.

title: Not for Amateurs
text: The tone of the writing is rather haughty. The system is hard to understand. Perhaps this is helpful to experienced chefs, but if you are simply a good cook looking for a helpful resource, don't bother.

title: Three Stars
text: I love this book but the copy I received is already falling out of its binding. This was disappointing.

title: beware the underlord book
text: Most of the books are fine, with the exception of non classroom appropriate words such as stupid, idiot, knucklehead, etc. But the book Rise of the Underlord is dark and evil. It gave my students nightmares, and I got an email from a parent to remove it from my class library. I had not read that one, but once I did was shocked. It was dark and the images and font were scary. This is not okay for first grade. The book has a worm gaining evil and growing a devil tail and horns. It ends as 'to be continued' with evil winning. The rest of the set is probably fine, but be advised on that book.

title: All about ordinary guy Joe and little about McCarthy -- or McCathyism
text:
It is too easy to knock this book, and it is a failure. This is a shame, since the author does a decent job of laying out his story, presenting the sequence of events in a turbulent period and avoiding stereotyping McCarthy as either extreme villain or underappreciated hero. He has obviously worked hard to find the right pitch and tone for his juvenile audience. The writing is crisp and clear.

But......

The choice of his "Joe" perspective and the treating of him as just one of the guys is a major misjudgment. I assume he wanted to avoid the type of demonization so marvelously captured in Richard Condon's novel The Manchurian Candidate, which is gloriously over the top, and the magnificent film version directed by John Frankenheimer, starring a superb Frank Sinatra and even more superb Angela Lansbury. He also tries not to be unfair (I choose the double negative here, because he omits assessment rather than makes conclusions) about the underlying concerns of the Red-baiters and HUAC that McCarthy exploited. (Truth in reviewing; I personally regard them as corrupt, shabby, vicious, mendacious, opportunistic, and devoid of scruple - words that I would apply to McCarthy.)

Rather than intrude my own views of the content, here are just a few short quotes from the book that you can use to judge for yourself the likelihood of your getting much insight from reading it. "This was not the first time... Joe was criticized for mistaking facts." "Joe anxiously awaited the results of the [tax] audit.... He was elated [he got a $1,00 refund].... Joe wasn't content to let the matter end there, however." He "loved to get revenge when he felt someone had treated him unjustly." Re Roy Cohn, of whom little good has ever been said and surely was about as vile a person as could be "I couldn't care less about your politics. I'm only interested in your ability to do the job." "He was also surprised and saddened he would not be welcome [to many Republican leaders] in their local elections in the fall." This last remark is about the impact of the Army hearings!

The author skips any in-depth discussion of the substance of the political background. That's understandable in trying to write a short book targeted to high schoolers. But there's no texture and key aspects of McCarthy's behavior are skimmed over. Nixon is mentioned only in passing. Roy gets a free pass. Towards the end, his "drinking heavily" is mentioned, but in passing. From all accounts, this was a sodden drunk. His motivations are not questioned. His vilification and persecutions of defenseless government and academic individuals are not explained or adequately detailed. While the author lays out facts accurately, they are never fleshed out or put in context. Watch any film or TV presentation of he hearings and the great Ed Murrow counterattack that become McCarthy's fall; the passion, anger, aggression and jousting of the many power players and the sheer drama are so far from the blandness of "then this happened.... Joe felt saddened."

I rate this a one-star book, more for what it is not than what it is. It is a workmanlike work (with interesting photos). It is not a solid or resonant portrayal of a figure whose name has become a cliché. That is, it throws little light on McCarthyism.

title: Simple
text: Somewhat simple, more of a children'sbook

title: A steampunk story by the modern master of robot stories.
text:
If there's anything Daniel H. WilsonDaniel H. Wilson is good at, it's writing about robots. In his latest book, The Clockwork Dynasty, he takes a steampunk approach by setting the book, not in the future, but in the present and distant past. Returning to the origins of robots via the automatons created for the entertainment of the wealthy and royal, Wilson has crafted another workable piece of fiction centered on robots. Unfortunately, as is the case with some of this other writing, I didn't like a few of his stylistic choices.

The Clockwork Dynasty jumps back and forth between flashbacks and "present era" actions, which can sometimes be distracting, especially if one of the storylines is particularly interesting at the time. I almost wonder if there could have been a better way to focus on the action in the present and to reveal the details of the past in more of a "show" instead of the "tell" provided via flashbacks. Additionally, I get why some of the violence was present in this book, but it (along with the few moments of obscenity or sex) seemed a little unnecessary.

One of my other qualms with this book was with the audiobook itself. Since the individuals reading each of the sections were different between the past and the present, it did help to know where I was in the story. However, the male voice of the past was a little quieter than the female voice of the present. This meant I turned up the volume each time the story was in a flashback, only to scramble to turn it down when the timeframe switched. Some volume leveling would have made this book a little less difficult to listen to, is all I'm saying.

A steampunk story by the modern master of robot stories, I give The Clockwork Dynasty 3.0 stars out of 5.

title: I wish there were zero stars!
text: After finishing Insurgent I was counting the days because I was so excited to read the next book. I went to the mailbox searching for my book. What a let down!! There were times I would zone out and have to look back to see whose perspective I was reading. There were so many missed opportunities this book had. Shame on you Ms. Roth! Going for shock value does not make you a better author!

title: Lost on the Mountain
text: This book is in desperate need of additional editing.  The story weaves from one subject to another until I almost lost track of it's theme.  Also, pictures of the characters involved would have added greatly to the readers attachment and understanding of the people and the story.  I almost thought I should read it again to see if I could get a better grasp of the story, but nixxed that idea quickly.

title: Traumatizing
text:
I assumed - wrongly - that I could trust a children's book to be appropriate for children. This book introduces a family, lets the reader invest in them, then kills all but two children, and the children carry a deep sadness for the rest of their lives.
I did not see or read the previous review, or I would have known. I am so sorry - my grandson was very distressed. Yes, of course it was a distressing event - but a child does not need to experience intimate, heartfelt loss from an historical event.

title: Not sure
text: Didn't like the path this book took with Darren. Not the outcome I would like. Don't care for the "hero" being a bad guy. Will read the next one to see what happens.

title: The cast was great, it's the story that has problems.
text:
The good.

The cast did a great job and really carried the story. I’ve seen some of them in shows but haven’t heard them doing audio books before. I’ll keep an eye out for them in other books.

The story was original. I had no idea what was coming next, unless it was something they were purposefully telegraphing in for a joke.

The bad.

The story is slow, the jokes are forced, the pop culture references run wild and free when someone really should have leashed them. I got the idea the author did a lot of research on the 60s and they’ll be dammed if they’re not going to use every scrap of it. It was too much by at least half.

title: Used for Class
text: This was a requirement for a course I was taking in college. Good book to use to get ready for ICD-10.

title: Believable tale
text:
Fast paced action tale that has a ring of possibility.

I felt that having Bill as a co author lends inside knowledge to how a President would have to live every second of every day.

Three and a half stars.

title: Two stories that should not be merged..
text:
There is a great history story in this book. A tragic important story that deserves to be told. There is also a harlequin romance story with a highly unlikely plot, ridiculous coincidences and lots of happily ever after. The two stories are polar opposites and should not be in the same book.
I liked the writing I just wish there was more history and less fantasy.

title: Fell short.
text: I generously gave this book 3 stars because it was a tight little story, appropriate for young readers, and I  didn't throw it through a window. I liked it enough to finish it, but when I  did, I  thought, "well, that was a waste of time." Where I  was looking for an evocation of magic and plot depth, this fell short of the mark.

title: nonessential actionscript
text: The author offers interesting takes on a number of topics, none of them of particular consequence. Many more interesting books available.

title: Why does the narrator follow this willful opportunist who uses then disposes?
text:

title: Some good info; poor editing makes for a hard read
text: I bought this book in preparation for opening a boarding facility at my farm. There are some good ideas, particularly for the person that is starting from scratch and doesn't know a lot about horses. However, the very poor editing (sentence fragments, typos, and generally poor grasp of English syntax) was extremely distracting. Several times, I almost abandoned the book. The author is not a natural-born writer, and perhaps should have utilized a co-author. As for content, one of the strengths is the organization of important points into questions the potential boarder can ask of a boarding facility, and a bullet list of observations that should be made when visiting potential sites. In summary, if the reader can tolerate the writing shortcomings of the book, the book's subject matter could be of help in making a wise boarding decision.

title: Sticks with you like resin from tobacco plants
text:
Though it has now been almost 30 years since I last spent a fall afternoon cutting tobacco, spearing the stalks onto wooden staves, and hanging the staves into the curing barn, I still remember the smell of the plants, the stickiness of the resin, the glint of the cutting and spearing tools. This tenuous link to a much earlier time, the time of the tobacco wars that rocked rural Kentucky and Tennessee just before WWII, provided me with just a sliver of insight to the hard times Robert Penn Warren depicts in his first novel, Night Rider.
The protagonist, Percy Munn, is an affable but pliable young lawyer, happily married with a growing law practice when he is drawn into supporting "The Association," an ardent band of tobacco farmers, including doctors, politicians, and other men whom "Perse" admires and who in turn admire him for his oratory skills, leadership, and status. Percy, himself a tobacco farmer, and the association work to break the economic monopoly exerted by the big tobacco companies (those bastards were evil well before they started lying to the public about the addictive nature of their deadly products). But when legal and ethical means are not enough, the collective leadership starts down a slippery slope of coercing nonassociation members to join or else face the consequences. Bands of "night riders" fan out across countryside, first destroying the crops of those who refused their entreaties to join up, then property, until even the taking of human life is justified as a means to their end once they have made the decision to torch the tobacco warehouses in Bardsville and the other towns in the vicinity.
Percy Munn finds himself at the center, and as other men whom he admired peel off from The Association because their moral bearing will not allow their continued participation, Percy eventually finds himself cut off from his wife; men such as Capt. Todd whom he greatly admired; Lucille Christian, the woman who tries to save him from himself; and eventually the leaders of The Association who let him take a fall for something he did not do.
The story is properly characterized as a tragedy even though Percy Munn is not as noble a central figure as one might expect. His great weakness is that he attaches himself to causes without much thought of the consequences. In other words, he is an idealist, but a flawed one. Though Percy's fall is in part caused by his flaws, a series of betrayals---sometimes he is the betrayer and other times he is betrayed---also conspire against him. When loyalty becomes more a currency than a principal, tragedy is inevitable.
Robert Penn Warren captures the speech and mannerisms of this main characters effectively, but he does not develop three-dimensional characters, with the exception of Willie Proudfit, the hard-scrabble, nearly destitute farmer who is something of a mystic who lives life fully and with a fervor Perse cannot experience as he continues his spiral inward. The landscape and settings seem more like those rendered by wood cuttings rather than a photograph. Some of Robert Penn Warren's digressions meander for pages without bolstering the story, and at times the allegorical and naturalistic elements of the novel seem at war with one another.
If permitted, I might rate this novel three and a half stars. Reading Night Rider is a worthwhile book for wintertime reading, butit is not the finest work by the author who was to become the first Poet Laureate of the United States.

title: A real page turner.
text:
The Charm School opens with a young American tourist, Gregory Fisher, driving in the Soviet Union's countryside in the 1980s. He makes an "illegal" stop to do some sightseeing and come across an American POW, recently escaped from a secret KGB training school where they force over 300 American POW's to teach Russians to think, act, and talk like Americans. There's no way Fisher could take the man with him to Moscow without them both being caught. Fisher calls the US Embassy as soon as he gets to his hotel and tells them what the man told him, but the KGB gets to Fisher before the US Embassy can.

Sam Hollis and Lisa Rhodes are the two diplomats who took the call. The Soviets insist that Fisher never checked into his hotel and in fact never reached Moscow, but was killed in when his car missed a turn and went off the road. Sam and Lisa volunteer to go retrieve the body in a ruse to get near the Charm School. They end up killing two guards and fleeing from the KGB after meeting Commander Burov, who unbeknownst to them is in charge of the school.

The story action slows down now but you get a good picture of life in the Soviet Union, and also of life in an embassy. Though many of the Russian peasants don't agree with their government, they are powerless to do anything about it. The government is basically ruling by terror - there is no such thing as a fair trial in the Soviet Union. You read how the common man lives day by day, paycheck to paycheck. The houses are run down, buildings are dilapidated, and the quality of life is very poor compared with Western standards. People will wait for hours in lines for fresh milk.

We are introduced to a Soviet officer who has given Sam Hollis much inside information. He offers Sam a list of over 3,000 names of Russians who have gone through the Charm School and are now living in America, in key positions in exchange for safe passage to the West for he and his granddaughter.

Sam and Lisa are soon declared persona non gratis by the Soviet Union and must leave. Predictably, their plane is grounded by a mysterious bomb threat and they are transferred to a Soviet Military helicopter where they are taken to the Charm School and given two choices - become instructors or be tortured and shot.

I won't spoil the ending for you, but I will say that though at times the book was predictable (though still enjoyable), the ending caught me completely by surprise and was perhaps a little sad.
This book is definitely a thriller. The beginning of the book kept you on the seat of your pants to find out what happens next, and the last two hundred pages or so were constant page turners. The only thing I didn't like, as with all Nelson DeMille novels, was the frequent foul language and the occasional sex scene, which really doesn't add anything to the story at all. That's why I only gave it 3 stars.

title: This book terrifies!
text:
At The End.

I don't want to mislead anyone, so I had to put that up first. I found this book by accident. I was looking for a book contest and came across the book trailer you see below. Instead, they found a wonderful apartment that had everything they wanted- even a small 'bonus' room for Susan's painting. Sadly, the cost was above their budget, their marriage and later, their sanity. At least Susan's sanity. She begins to think the $3,500 a month apartment is haunted, then is more than convince the place is infested with - 'Gasp!' - Bedbugs!

I wasn't impressed and very disappointed. Words like BORING, and ANTICLIMACTIC I will say no more.

title: No Dignity For Lynne's Last Days
text:
Lynne’s Last Christmas- A Battle With Dementia was just heart breaking to read. I was friends with Lynne when we met at a Westgate Doll Show back in 1980. If you knew the real Lynne, as I did, you would never write about her most torturous end of her life. Lynne was very private, hiding behind a perfect front that she had to put on every day. Just knowing that these horrific moments of her end, would be shared with others, would make her beyond sad forever.

Lynne and I were a month apart, and when we went to our doll shows or meetings, we had such fun. She told me, this was the only place she could be herself, without having to be the perfect wife, perfect hostess, perfect daughter or perfect mother. She was so sad about life’s problems and imperfections, as she only wanted everything perfect, like the person she forced herself to be. Lynne shared with me all the things in life, that she just couldn’t cope with- having rats in her beautiful home on Wooster coming up through every opening in the home, due to Rocky River’s sewer issues with rats. She would call me up crying, that she opened her kitchen drawer and there were dead rats in her kitchen towels. Then she dealt with her beloved son going through cancer and the thought of him not getting well took up all her energy. As if this wasn’t enough, her husband was going to leave her for one of his co-workers. Lynne’s perfect exterior couldn’t cope with real life and this took her mentally down. She told me divorce was out of the question, being the perfect Catholic.

Lynne loved our Barbie Doings at The Bain Cabin and at each other’s homes. Whenever it was her turn to have us over at her home, she told me, Don wouldn’t approve, as all our entertaining is for his or our friends, not mine. She lived a life for others, never for herself. She loved being the perfect mom more than anything. I often wonder if any of her family ever knew the real Lynne that I knew, imperfect, frightened of everything. The book itself would make Lynne eternally sad to hang all her dirty laundry out for everyone to see. Her image of perfection was what she lived for. Lynne was so proud of her cooking skills, and I can still see her eating her famous potato salad at our Barbie meeting at the Bain Cabin. How she loved the compliments. Lynne was a very fragile, wonderful, fun friend whose perfect exterior hid the frightened little girl inside. I truly wish this book was written without her name attached to it, as she deserves way better. A 3 STAR book with no dignity for Lynne’s last days.

title: Good Price
text: Okay pics.

title: Mom loves it, son is less interested
text: I adore this book, and feel like it has a great message about how everyone has something to offer. (I also am amused by how the cover reads as "Swaggy dogs, waggy dogs," which might also be an awesome book.) The illustrations are bright and engaging, and the prose has a great rhythm to it. My only concern is that I seem to like the book more than my 3-year-old... so I have to give it three stars because it seems to be kid tested, but only mom-approved. :/

title: Three Stars
text: Pretty repetitive. Pointing out the obvious.

title: Too Many Loose Ends
text: I loved the book the way I loved Anne's earlier works. The description of the house (which is its own character) and the surrounding land, the characters as they interacted and learned and developed and revealed themselves to me, the reader. It was a tightly woven story, rich with color and promise almost up until the end, and then it fizzled. The distinguished gentlemen who roused my curiosity early on were not nearly developed enough, nor was Laura, who just appeared and seemed almost passive to the extraordinary relationship and then drifted off into nothing at the end. It's like the author lost interest in actually finishing the book and rushed through the ending. I can only hope that there will be a sequel to flesh things out and answer the burning questions!

title: Thought there would be more...
text: I first ordered Extraordinary Things to Cut Out and Collage by Maria Rivans, by comparison, Handmade Collage doesn't stand up. Firstly, you're not so much getting a book of art for collages of your choice, but rather recreating the collages the author has created. All of the photographs are matte paper, not shiny, and I'm not sure if I love it or hate it as I've not used a single piece in this book. While one can cut the objects out and use them for their own creations, it is rather limited, and weirdly themed. I haven't found it useful for what I'm working on. Secondly, I have absolutely no intentions or interest in recreating someone else's art! I find that aspect incredibly odd. This book could be so much better. I wish it was a book of collage pieces usable for one's own creations. I honestly wouldn't buy this again. I think I'm going to give it to my 11 year old so she can recreate these peices.

title: Simple Story
text: A simple story, somewhat like a Hallmark Channel movie, for those who don't want complex character development or suspense. The reading is easy. This could have been written for fifth graders. Still, it is warm and cozy, like a flame in your fireplace on a snowy December night.

title: 2 stars
text:
Honestly this was one of the dullest books I've ever read. The characters felt like they did nothing at all. I mean seriously they wandered around and just sort of happened upon things that started to make sense within the case. Leaphorn was more worried about his wife (rightfully so) then he was about actually catching a murderer on the reservation. Chee felt like that only truly intelligent character and yet very little time felt like it was spent on him as a police officer. The pacing was so slow I actively went out of my way to find other things to do rather then read. I almost had to bribe myself to even finish 15 pages a night so I could finish the book before my book club met up to discuss it.

Of the entire 216 pages only the last 25 or so were actually something I enjoyed. I only enjoyed the last 10% of the book because it was the only part where things actually happened and the "police" (I use that term very loosely in this as they were mostly just lucky and not actually good at their jobs) managed to mostly figure out what was going on. We won't talk about the fact that they weren't even the ones to take down the bad guy because that just felt like a low blow from the author. We also won't discuss the fact that said bad guy was mentioned a total of around 10 by name. We met the person once and then BOOM, the bomb is dropped that they are the bad guy. Where did that even come from?

Westerns are definitely not my favorite thing, be them movies or books, so this was already starting off not well. Between the actual writing, the pacing, and the extraordinarily poor characters I can honestly say I will not be picking up another Tony Hillerman book in the future. Even though technically this is book seven in the series I didn't feel like I was missing any vital information, other then who the lady Chee kept mentioning, was. I felt like everything could be read on it's own and for that I am thankful.

Check out more reviews on beautyandthebookwormonline.wordpress.com

title: Sadly, overall, this much anticipated tale seemed forced and flat
text:
This was my second attempt to finish Dr. Sleep, which I did this time around. The first time I tried, when it was released, I was uninterested in the plot and its characters, so I put it away when I reached the halfway mark. On this second attempt, I started again from the beginning and I discovered that the 2nd half is much more interesting and faster-paced than the 1st half.

I won't give spoilers here, but I will reveal why a 3-star review. It is a high D or low C on a grading scale, for me. I don't particularly find Dan Torrence’s adult story engaging; it is really just kind of boring. Dan has his life struggles, most of which have resulted from his father's alcoholism and Overlook possession-there are lots of personal internal and external conflicts and demons Dan needs to trap, yet he is a boring guy, so the story is not too engaging in the first half of the story.

OK, time for some MILD SPOILERS: Additionally, I didn’t find the antagonists (the True Knot) really menacing/threatening (I kind of envision them as a band of roving decaying circus vampires); King made the heroine too strong for the True Knot. The situations and conflicts created by the True Knot should be suspenseful, but I never felt tension with the telepathic battles. Many times, I just wanted the story to be over, faster. I think that this would have made a good novella. There were just too many pages that could have been ripped out and still not affected the continuity of the story. In fact, a tighter story may have engaged readers more successfully. But maybe not...

The book has its moments that drew me in and flowed well (and this was mainly in the 2nd half), but overall, this was a story that did not give this Shining fan any satisfaction.

In the end, I was really interested in looking into the lives of Danny and Wendy and Doc once again, and now, after reading Dr. Sleep, I wish I would have left the sleeping giant slumber.

title: Not Completely Grounded
text:
"No hobby cases, Harry."

That's the message from Cliff O'Toole, the new lieutenant heading up the Open-Unsolved Unit. O'Toole thinks Bosch is overly fixated on a murder case that started during the Rodney King riots in Los Angeles, twenty years ago.

Says O'Toole: "You are the worst kind of police officer, Bosch. You are arrogant, you are a bully, and you think the laws and regulations simply don't apply to you. I'm not the first to attempt to rid this department of you. But I will be the last."

Bosch, of course, put the T in tenacious and he'll even go ahead and take a `vacation' to pursue a lead. Harry Bosch has a bullet casing--a bullet casing found near the body of a female photojournalist who was murdered in an alley and now, given the intervening two decades, Bosch can put it under more scrutiny with new technology at his disposal. And he has personal motivation. Bosch had been one of the cops to find the body during the riots.

Bosch struggles for space and freedom to pursue his instincts against the grain of police bureaucracy. Bosch follows every single scrap of evidence like the master sleuth we admire, blowing through apparent dead ends and seeing things that others have not.

Bosch is pursuing the "one thing that brings it all together and makes sense of things. You find it and you're gold."

For the most part, "The Black Box" works. Bosch follows the victim's past and starts making links to a moment on a cruise ship that was used for R & R for soldiers in the Gulf War.

For me, several things didn't quite click. I didn't think O'Toole's anger at Bosch was warranted. Bosch's alleged crimes within department rules seemed relatively minor. Yes, he wandered slightly outside of protocol, but his steps didn't seem to justify putting a fellow cop out on the street to trail Bosch--a cop who plays a critical role in coming to Bosch's aid at the end. And once Bosch follows his leads up to central California, I had the feeling that Connelly wanted Harry Bosch to teach Jack Reacher a thing or two about toughness and guile. The Hollywood-esque ending felt a bit over-the-top.

Harry Bosch is one of the best at breaking down a case, figuring things out, asking questions, pursuing every angle and, of course, never giving up. He's also a rogue cop, albeit a rogue with heart. "The Black Box" is a good read but I wish the climax had its feet as firmly on the ground as the first four-fifths of the story.

title: What took him so long?
text:
THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS FOR THOSE WHO HAVE NOT READ THE BOOK!
This is an interesting book. I enjoyed reading it because it chronicles one of America's greatest music groups, and shows what went on behind the scenes of that perfection machine known as The Eagles. Granted, that inside glimpse comes from Felder's perspective, but it is the only expose` I have read that shines some light on the dysfunction within this group.

Felder tells of his humble beginnings in Gainesville, Florida; his growing love of music; the sibling rivalry caused by being compared to his brother; and his own reckless behavior that caused a long-lasting rift with his parents.

He was complimentary of his fellow band-mates, quick to give praise to the musicians who helped him get his start in the music industry. He even admitted to his personal failings while touring on the road. It is not every man who can stand up and tell the world that he drank, did drugs and cheated on his wife. One thing came through clearly and repeatedly as he told his story, Don Felder did love his wife Susan and their four children. Having said that, I wondered about Felder's cavalier attitude in explaining away his behavior.

It was mildly annoying that when speaking of Don Henley and Glenn Frye, they were always referred to as "The Gods." I found it self-aggrandizing that Felder constantly patted himself on the back for his accomplishments; but this is, after all, his biography. It was difficult to read about his emotional weakness at the time Henley and Frey ended his partnership with the Eagles.

The manner in which Felder informed his wife that their marriage was over was disturbing. The fact that he found a girlfriend before either he or his wife had filed for divorce, was more than a minor character flaw. I will always love the music of the Eagles. I have Felder's album "Airborne," and I think he is a gifted musician; but this book truly changed my opinion of Don Felder the man.

The reader never gets to the truth behind the title of the book until it nears its conclusion, by then I asked myself what took him so long.
