title: Not living up to the promise
text: I've reached the "Difficult" section and I still do not feel particularly challenged. They are adding the phrase ("two words") to any of the clues in any section that are in fact, a two-word answer. Maybe some publishers still do that in easy puzzles, but most publishers of the difficult puzzles don't offer that bit of assistance. I was excited to get this book, but I must admit I am disappointed and will not order any other editions if offered.

title: Missing something...
text: I was looking forward to listening to this audiobook, especially because I loved that it was read by Joe himself. I, too, was born & raised in the Bronx. However, even after growing up in the Bronx & being familiar with many of the places & streets mentioned in this book, I still found it difficult to relate. Although I knew families who did live a life of drugs and had some financial success in it, I guess none that lived in my building or went to my schools were at the same level of success as Joe. This book was great in many ways, but it was missing something. I wish it were geared more towards inspiring others so that they, too, can overcome hardships and meet whatever goal it is they desire. It was missing that component for me. The Bronx is such a difficult place to go to school & grow up in. It is so easy to feel unnoticed & like you don't matter in a city of that many people & in that much darkness. I was hoping this book was more uplifting & providing hope for those still living there, but unfortunately, in my opinion, it did not. This is why I give it 3 out of 5 stars.

title: Was good
text: Though it was interesting to read, I feel it was too short. I was really getting into the book and bam, the end.

title: THIS BOOK IS FULL OF INACTURIES-JUST GOT BACK
text: WE ARE IN OUR 80S AND USED THIS BOOK TO PLAN OUR VISIT TO ARUBA.  DRESS CODE, NO PLASTIC BOTTLES, NO NICOTINE, NO CAMOUFLAGE CLOTHING, AND MOST IMPORTANTLY FEREE SHUTTLE  ALL AROUND THE ISLAND.  WE BOOKED AT THE BRICKELL BEACH SPA DUE TO THE SHUTTLE PASSING AT THE FRONT DOOR. THIS MAY HAVE BEEN TRUE BEFORE THE PANDEMIC, BUT THE POPULATION WAS ABOUT 70 THOUSAND, BUT ON NOVEMBER 14 IT WAS SUPPOSEDLY 20 THOUSAND PERMANENT RESIDENTS.  DO NOT BUY THIS BOOK AND PLAN YOUR TRIP.  THE PEOPLE WERE EXTREMELY NICE WHICH MADE UP FOR THE LACK OF SERVICES.  WE PACKED TOO MANY CLOTHES DUE THE THE DESCRIPTIONS IN THE BOOK!

title: Arrow to the Heel
text:
Achilles shoots off with a fast paced plot that never lets up. It's like a Marvel movie with non-stop action. Wow! I thought, this is great escapist SyFy until I kept reading. Written in present tense, the plot shoots along in a blur of characters that leaves the reader wonder what the hey haw is going on. Where are these kids from originally and why are they fighting each other all the time? Didn't they read Lord of the Flies? Aren't they all from the same planet? They must be from earth since they're all self-absorbed and put themselves first. How many times is the main character, Jonah, going to let somebody get the drop on him? Which character is likeable enough to root for? I wanted Jonah to develop into a hero, but alas he couldn't see his way to step up to the plate, especially after he lost his eyesight.
This book started fast, but bogged down into repetitive confrontations and illogical surprises. The teenagers in the book do too many stupid things to make them believable. Boose can write but now he needs to tell a story a teenager will enjoy. (Never understimate the intelligence of a teenaged science fiction fan.)

title: A interesting group of stories
text: A group of stories of life on present day indian reservation.  The people are well written about and it will keep your interest all the way through.

title: Many errors!
text: Don’t recommend it. I am currently using it and even though many of the questions are helpful, there are many errors and inconsistencies such as asking for the option that reduces the risk for hypoglycemia and the answer and rationale in the back being the one that causes hypoglycemia.

title: Meaningful Message for Parents and Children!
text: I gave this book to a little relative for Christmas.  I do think the message is great for parents and children.  However, I do have other reasons for not giving it five stars.  Perhaps the material quality of the book could be better.

title: One Star
text: Stilted and dated, kinda dry. Not my cup of tea.

title: Really really bad
text: The very second "riddle" sets the tone for the rest of the book.  It's worded in such a way that there's actually 2 answers, but the writer seems unaware of this since these's no mention of that in the "answers" section, just the one the writer was able to come up with.  The rest of the riddles don't have 2 obvious answers (that I was able to find, anyway), but they are all obviously written by someone who is not familiar with writing good riddles.  The other aspects of the book, like pattern recognition, and math problems are similarly written by an amateur.  I wasn't able to get very far into the second half because the quality of "brain teaser" didn't improve.  They were a little more challenging, but still not written well or particularly clever.

title: A Screed Filled with Stereotypes and Disconstruction
text: Gail Collins ventured to Texas with the air of an anthropologist gone to examine the quaint customs of the natives in some far away country. She has come to the sort of conclusions that one would expect an effete, New York liberal to arrive at. When she is not stereotyping the Lone Star State, which is far more diverse than she thinks, she is trashing its history under the guise of deconstruction. Her main beef is that Texas has found a means of ordering society, business friendly, respectful of individual liberty, but tough on criminals, that works far better than the liberal welfare state. This makes her very angry and snarky and it shows in her writing.

title: This book wasn’t helpful for me
text: i liked that this came with a CD so you could here examples of special effects, etc. but truthfully, I had trouble understanding how to put into practice what was being described in the text. Photos of how to hold the bow were helpful...I wish there were more photos. Also, I thought there would be more practical tips, such as exercises for improving intonation. There was a section on learning vibrato, which I found useful. But most of the book was either too advanced for me to understand or not explained very well.

title: Good mystery, slow reading
text: It felt like the book just stayed at the same pace the whole time, not a lot of excitement but an interesting story line.

title: Un Viaje Lento
text:
I am a fan of historical fiction, especially mysteries. In my youth I read every one of the [[ASIN:0060751401 Judge Dee Mysteries]] by Robert Van Guilin several times each. As with this book, they are full of sex and violence as well as historical information. One thing each of the Judge Dee books had was a Dramatis Personae: a list of all the named characters, something this novel sorely needs, because there are dozens of characters who maddeningly pop in and out. Put the book down for a few days, and you are likely to forget who is who.

For an historian, especially a British historian, it’s disappointing how many anachronisms are contained within these pages. The story takes place in the the mid-sixteenth century (1584), but late in the narrative, the country doctor gives the hero laudanum, something which was unknown until the 1660s. Likewise, Carr has people firing rifles. Firearms with a rifled bore (hence the name) were not made until the next century. Carr lists two weapons historians he consulted, yet he puts safety catches on matchlock pistols. (He’s off by three-hundred years on that one.)

There is a rich history of sixteenth-century Spain, but the novel is not worth it. Worst of all are all the descriptive passages which make reading this a rough slog. There are several road trips, each with detailed descriptions of the countryside and villages. The journey from Valladolid to Belamar takes the protagonists twelve days. It may take the reader the same amount of time to trudge through those pages.

title: There’s a reason for the title…
text: There was a lot of hype about this book — totally unfounded.

title: That Sinking Feeling
text:
The Doctor and Charley arrive in future Venice hours before it sinks. Can an ancient curse be reversed in time to save the great city?

This story is filled with familiar, perhaps even stereotypical, characters. There is an unsavoury Duke, a strange old woman, a mutated human, and followers of a strange cult. All these things have long been staples of Doctor Who, but for some reason this story failed to grab me. Instead I found it to be rather formulaic.

There is, however, no denying the incredible rapport between Paul McGann and India Fisher. This is the first story the pair recorded, but their character seem like old friends. Their performances are truly the best thing about this audio.

2.5 stars

title: Another good holiday read
text:
Like most of Katia Lief's novels, "Next Time You See Me" (aka "[[ASIN:B00563M3I8 Hide and Seek]]" -- its UK title) is an above-averagely penned thriller, which makes for an excellent novel for a long plane flight, or an idle few days on the beach. The story is a sequel to the "[[ASIN:0091937914 You Are Next]]" but does not require the reader to have read the earlier work. Indeed, its plot line spins out in an entirely new direction, although readers of the earlier volume may find themselves wondering more than a few times whether it will suddenly tie into the earlier one in some meatier sort of a way.

Like its predecessor, the book would convert effortlessly and effectively into a screenplay; it has the right mix of action and dialogue, a comfortable cast size and a sufficiently simple (simplistic almost) plot-line but with a potent narrative capable of delivering a comfortable suspension of disbelief through an atavistic response to the story's emotional flow, rather than needing any rational figuring of the events themselves.

Also like its predecessor, the book delivers no real surprises, but neither does it disappoint; it's worth more than three stars really but doesn't quite deserve four.

title: Worth a Double Take
text: I am a lover of the FBI Series and this one sure does not change my mind.

title: Disappointed
text: Definitely would not recommend this to anyone. Characters were flat, and there was nothing unique about the story. Boring book.

title: This is pretentious prose. When you read Gomrich's "A ...
text: This is pretentious prose. When you read Gomrich's "A little History of the World" with its stunningly clear writing, Mieville's book is the exact opposite. I'm reading it because I'm interested in the topic. I just wished he had aimed for clarity. I'm halfway through, painfully, always hoping that the author will finally lighten up.

title: One Star
text: Boring!

title: If it was as good as the title
text: I'm not one to give away the ending to a novel. Even an ending, if you can call it that,as absurd as this one. So, let's start with the characters. Qui-Gon and Obi-Wan need no introduction. However, there is this character Rael Averross,who is supposed to be a Jedi, but dresses like a slob, smokes, drinks alot, sleeps around and doesn't seem to have anything to do with " The Force ". Also, he made a bad decision, that obviously should not have been made, that got his Padawan killed. Ok so the Jedi Council sends him off to rule a planet until its princess , who is a child, is old enough to be crowned Queen. Really? This guy can't handle the job so he asks for back up namely Qui-Gon with Obi-Wan his Padawan, who are at odds for most of the story because they each think they have failed the other. Also, the Jedi Council has invited Qui-Gon to join the Council. Now Qui-Gon  believes in old Jedi prophecies, which the others including Obi-Wan don't, and he actually seems to be one with The Force, when needed. He has a record of being at odds with the Council at times and a bit of a free thinker which master Yoda certainly doesn't care for since he voted against the invite.  So, before Qui-Gon decides off they go to help Rael. They get there and the story drags on and on about the usual corporate greed, mining, using slaves, etc. Now there's a story line involving a couple of jewl thieves that should've been completely left out, imho, since it takes away from the main plot, which is infantile at best, again imho. There's a group of bad guys who are good guys that actually want to save the planet from the other bad guys etc. It's a mess but not one that makes sense in the end. Real is so useless as a Jedi he doesn't have a clue as to what's going on  even at the end when his precious child Queen, whom he adores, turns on him and loathes him more than any other creature in the galaxy. A generous 2 stars for Qui-Gon whose character saved the novel from total trash.

title: One Star
text: Not helpful

title: Unresolved
text:
Let me start off by saying a few misspelled words are no big deal to me, but this book has words missing or completely out of context for the sentence. Some serious editing ( beyond spell check) is needed in this book.

Apart from that I was enjoying the story until the end when the female lead refuses to provide any info on what she knew about Olympus and flew off into the wilds. The male lead doesn't pursue the matter. Nothing is even mentioned about what, if anything, happens to the people who burned a man alive. Nor is anything mentioned about the other deaths. Nothing at all is resolved. We are just supposed to close the book and toddle off? Poor, poor ending -- as if the author ran out of ideas and just typed "The End".

Three stars for the first part of the book and two stars off for the lousy ending.

title: I trudged through it as I thought it a good opportunity to familiarize myself with Joyce Carol Oates
text: Poetically written, with a schizophrenic slant. Extremely hard to get through. I forced myself to finish this because I've have kept this book for so many years and never got around to reading it. I trudged through it as I thought it a good opportunity to familiarize myself with Joyce Carol Oates. It took so long (p 200/236) to get to the punch line that I forgot there was a finale to be had. Painstaking telling juxtaposed with beautiful writing. I will try not to force myself to finish reading anything I'm not into in the future.

title: Good for frosting and decorating.
text: I've been baking successfully for 45 years. I've tried 3 recipes from this book and didn't care for any of them. My family and I found them dry. Today I made peanut butter cakes. I could barely taste the peanut butter and I threw them away. This is the last time I'll waste my time and money. Obviously from all the good reviews people like this book. I'd be very interested to know how many of these good reviews come from using cake mix since cake mix cakes are usually very moist. The reason I gave a 3 star rating is because there's so many cute decorating ideas and tips and ideas for unusual frosting flavors.

title: Good book for music historians
text: This is a good, easy to read (I mean real easy...like it's written for a child) book about the career of Tommy James, how and why he wrote some of his songs (I enjoyed about the origin of the song "mony,mony") and how he was controlled by mobsters that influenced radio and record sales. I especially loved his compliments or insults of fellow pop artists. The main weakness of the book is that the narrative sugarcoats his own life and treats his failed marriages in too light of a manner. This is hardly intellectual fodder but it makes for a good "beach read".

title: A sad and poorly written commentary on firefighting
text: Larry Brown has written “On Fire - a personal account of life and death choices.” To this reader, this “fireman’s diary” falls far short of print worthy. From Brown’s elementary voice to the boastful fanfare of the world of firefighting, this 181-page narrative was mostly disappointing. His depiction of firefighters as beer swilling buffoons whose main interest is watching sex and violence on television stands in odd contrast to his sense of self importance as a life saver. Fortunately today’s fire service largely enjoys a higher level of education and professionalism than that described in the book. It is puzzling that Brown received high profile blurbs from the likes of John Grisham and New York Times Book Review.

title: The Utopia of Apocalyptic Novels!
text:
“I grew up in the Apocalypse, yet I still felt as if I belonged in another time.”

Wyatt Sullivan woke up in an abandoned bus in a time where deserts are the natural landscape and Feral beasts roam the earth looking to tear you to shreds. Smart and resourceful, he’s managed to keep himself alive for years with gadgets and gizmos until one day his radio signal picks up a human voice. He follows it, comes face to face with death, and wakes up with a cybernetic arm that grants him awesome powers. Will he use his newfound powers to save humanity? Or join the dark side?

The concept and science behind this book are extremely interesting. The physics of how the technology works while affecting the landscape are explained in a way that made me believe this could all really happen and that I understand how time/space dimensions work. (I don’t know anything about time/space dimensions.) I got Mad Max vibes mixed with Terminator - a duo I can appreciate.

However, I will say, a lot fell flat for me. I think this book could have greatly benefited from line editing, cuts on repetitive expositions, and more in-depth dives into the world itself and how Wyatt came to function properly after being alone for so long without memories. There wasn’t really a climax or any character development - everything happened exactly the way a good guy would want it to happen with evil doers turning good the moment of conflict which is not very believable. I would’ve liked to have seen Wyatt dip his toes into evil for a moment rather than be this string of holy consciousness and I would’ve liked to have seen more evil acts and betrayal from our dear Mr. Mayor to make me really hate him.

Overall, awesome concept just too good to be true for me.

title: Stupid is as stupid does
text:
I write this for those who are not deterred by the negative reviews. I wasn't! wasn't expecting much, but at least hoped for some fun. Wikipedia is actually my idea of fun so I at least thought a thriller about fun things like codes and history and conspiracy theories such would be at least entertaining, even if the majority of the book consisted of People Talking About Things. Moreover, my standards for popular paperback thrillers are low (if people are complaining about the terrible writing, they clearly haven't read many bestseller thrillers. I mean, somebody want to defend the literary skills of Rollins or Grisham etc? Bahaha).

Where do I begin with the Stupid? I will not bore you with a laundry list. Suffice it to say that the first time any character does anything remotely intelligent is in chapter *110* when a CIA agent notices wheelchair marks in the carpet (no worries, not a spolier and nothing any generic detective wouldn't figure out).

I am a fan of far-fetched plots so long as they're logical within their world, so to speak. I'll suspend disbelief as long as the storytelling is good. I'll even excuse the bloated and formulaic plotting since I have a ffwd button I don't mind using as the same pointless details/dialog are repeated for the 110th time. But all of the above is so dumb I could only imagine that Brown was making stuff up as he went along. Plot twists actually rely on people doing stupid, illogical things. This is not fun.

Critics have panned Brown for his latest book being nothing but a glorified travel guide, and even that doesn't bother me! So long as it's interesting and absorbing enough. I didn't mind the Dan Brown Wikipedia Lectures in the beginning...until the story began to fall so flat that my mind would start wandering as I imagined Dan Brown on his 3-day tour of DC grabbing museum brochures and recording docent lectures. Not that I don't like museum brochures. I just don't want to see Dan Brown copying them on his computer, I'd rather be able to imagine characters in those places, which my visions of Dan Brown on Tour kept blocking.

Critics have panned Robert Langdon as being supercilious and obnoxious as he lectures everyone because he's smarter than everyone else. Lecture away, professor, so long as what you have to say is actually professor-like! Okay, true, there are lots of misinformed supercilious professors out there. However! The Internet! Libraries! People who know more about a subject than you the writer and can easily be interviewed! More than one book on a topic! Robert Langdon is, in this book, weirdly uninformed about certain religious texts he spouts off about. I've been annoyed by cheap research in other thrillers too, but Langdon should know better! So should his esoteric buddies.

I'm telling all of y'all, I should've gotten some enjoyment out of this book. My standards were low, I'm a nerd who likes lectures, I have no fear of skipping pointless passages. But I wasted my time! I should've taken a clue from the Wikipedia article on this book that was probably buffed up by a publicist trying to rebut criticisms of the book...I wondered why even Hollywood dropped the story and politely moved on to Inferno instead. I imagine that, in spite of having paid Brown a ton of moola for it, they eventually had to realize it no amount of script doctoring could make it into more than a terribly boring movie.

Anyway, if you're still not deterred, I strongly suggest instead of dropping your hard-earned money on this disappointing story that you borrow this from your local library (tons of *free!* electronic books/audiobooks if you knew not) and be ready to listen to it on 1.5x with your finger on the ffwd button.

title: Not so much.
text: While this book was at times witty, charming, and thought-provoking, mostly it was a very cumbersome read. The thoughts and ideas presented kept going around in circles like something that goes around in circles a lot!! The endless footnotes (nearly every page) kept interrupting what little logical flow sporadically existed. While the footnotes did give the impression that well researched material was being presented, they crossed the line from footnote/s into foot fungus. A persistent itching, that never seems to go away. The end result was that I could only read about 20 pages at a time, before I became uninterested in what might come next. The time I wasted could have been better spent doing my own research on the internet, instead of reading what Mary found in a google search.

title: A lot of build up for... *spoiler alert*
text: I usually don't write reviews for books. People read what they want to read. I stumbled upon this author trying to find another great ghost story. I started with one of his trilogies and liked it so well I wanted another one. This one sounded good. It started off great but as the story moved along and the woman was seeing and hearing all of the knocks and faces with masks and telling her unbelievable husband who had a reason for everything it was just drug out so long AND THEN ***SPOILER ALERT**' the author goes and KILLS Her?! Not where I thought it would go. Then the husband finds her and knows she's dead and HER body disappears and it felt like days he went in search of it in the forest that wasn't a forest but just dead trees. AND THEN what the Hell was the baby, child, monster thing anyway? Oh. And I hated the ending. It felt like he was trying to meet a deadline so he wrapped it up with not only the previous owners who built the place but the couple that bought the house lurking as ghosts I guess. Sorry, I'm not sorry I wrote a bad review.

title: 3.5 stars
text:
I liked the premise. The female character Ellia has a two year gap in her memory of people and events after an accident. She remembers her life up until freshman year and nothing about her boyfriend, Liam, of the past two years. They have a sweet love that is envied by many around them. Their love story (told in flashbacks) is put on hold as Ellia tries to navigate her new world. A world in which she isn't sure she wants Liam to be a part of and she continually pushes him away the harder he tries to remain a part of her life.

Parts of the story didn't work for me because no rebelling teenage girl is going to pick the nerdy good guy. That's not the type of person that's going to keep your parents up at night. I also find that the flashbacks were distracting and it took me completely out of the story.

This is not your typical teen romance but I liked the messages that were conveyed: 1) Sometimes, you have to know when to give up on the past and make a brand new start and; 2) you have to know who the "I" is in I love you ... which are words to live by.

title: Don't bother, not worth over $40
text:
This book is way too basic. For the price it is a terrible value. Some of the advice seems outdated or useless, such as letting people know that they can get forms from the IRS website, or use tax software. They spend an entire chapter on setting up an office. I don't mean choosing an office space. I mean things like, you will need a phone, copier, and office supplies. I was expecting more of a textbook on how to operate a practice, including procedures, marketing, etc. The marketing chapter is virtually useless as well, with no novel ideas; network, tell your friends, do a direct mail campaign, etc. If it were 20 bucks, I would have kept it. For almost 50, I had to return it. I rarely if ever return an item, so that says how strongly I felt the value was not there. I purchased instead, "The Enrolled Agent Tax Consulting Practice Guide: Learn How to Develop, Market, and Operate a Profitable Tax and IRS Representation Practice" http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B004RCLYIE/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_4
For $7.99 in the Kindle edition it has much more valuable ideas. Even if not an EA trying to focus on representation it has better value. It also has interviews with actual practitioners on how they run their practices.
If you are absolutely clueless as to how to even set up an office it might have some value, otherwise steer clear.

title: A major work on the subject
text:
I did not realize this is a reprint of a 1990 book I read as a hardback. I would not have ordered it if I had. This is not a bad history in terms of accuracy, notes, use of sources, reasons or conclusions. The author drills down into the social, cultural and political issues of New York. He details how these items contribute to the worst riot in our history. This is a very detailed work with a good set of maps to supplement the text.
It is one of if not the standard work on the riot. In addition, it is a cure for insomnia. This is a very difficult book to read. For a person interested in labor history and social issues from the 1850s to 1890s this is a great book. If you are looking for information on the draft riot, this is the book but it is a difficult read.

title: Fictional Japanese characters come to life

The family histories are fascinating and the characters compelling.  We learn a great deal about the Japanese expat commnity in NY and the upper class in Japan.  It is a nice change from the typical books about Samurai and Geisha.  The book was very long, though.  I think some editing would have been helpful.

title: Disjointed and short on detail but conveys the horror.
text:
Caruso was a Lieutenant in the 9th Marines, 3rd Marine division, which he joined towards the end of its time on Guam. He was involved in only one combat incident there but his two weeks on Iwo saw him exposed to a lot more. Unfortunately these are generally presented in short vignettes, sometimes with minimal detail and a lack of context in terms of when it took place. There are a few occasions where he does go into more detail, like when he is under attack at night, with grenades landing in his foxhole but mostly he is too sparse with the details and it is clear he left a lot out. There are quite a few passages provided by fellow veterans and some of these are quite graphic. They serve, to an extent, in fleshing Caruso's story out a little more. Caruso also includes some potted histories for some of the men he knew who were killed. Altogether these certainly convey the horror of the battle but Caruso's own story is lost at times.

Caruso was clearly the real deal as a soldier. The five officers above him were all first day casualties and he found himself commanding the company - from the front - almost from the start. He does provide some interesting information regarding some of his decisions but mostly he is writing about his interactions with his brother marines. Many of these become casualties and he provides statistics that emphasize the scale of these. By the time he is wounded less than 40 men are left in his company.

This is a short book that can easily be read in a few hours. It is based on some articles Caruso did about the campaign, which were apparently very well received by fellow veterans. Perhaps because of this, it is closer to a memorial to his comrades than a typical personal memoir - it is just not complete enough for me for that. It doesn't conform to a traditional narrative structure and Caruso doesn't build his story. Accordingly, in my opinion, it fails to engage the reader. I'd have liked to give it 2 1/2 stars. It is still informative in a general way though and the tragedy of it all is very clear. But there are other memoirs (see my list) where it is all revealed in a more complete and compelling manner. My recomemendation - Of some interest.

I give one star to the book because of the art, which is not particulary good regarding characters, but the backgrounds are just fantastic.

Regarding the plot, it turned out to be to slow for me. It tells the story of a young Clark Kent becoming Superman. One story each station.

Most of the book turns to be a vanilla experience in Smallville and what it takes to Clark to go to Metropolis and start wearing the red cape. Is nice and slow, but is a SUPERMAN COMIC. It should have more action.

title: Average book, possibly OK for beginners
text: I love to cook and I am familiar with Paleo cooking. This cookbook is well laid out and provides a lot of information, but the biggest drawback was the lack of pictures! I appreciate all the time and energy that goes into creating cookbooks and that these are truly 1 pot meals. Aside from that, as I flipped through the pages, nothing spoke to me or inspired me into motion to even make 1 recipe. I do intermittent fasting, so the entire breakfast section would be one I wouldn't even entertain, but perhaps there are recipes my children may eat.

title: Miniature book that is totally lame.
text: I am pissed. The book is tiny--it is smaller than a deck of cards. The illustrations are cheap copies and reproduced at a size that crops out much of the original work by Schulz, and for such a small book, reading isn't so much a pleasure as looking at the illustrations, for which there are VERY FEW and mostly just pages and pages and pages of watered-down, ill-adapted text in a font that looks like my two year old son cut and pasted it from a random web site. I feel totally swindled, no where in the description does it clue you in to the genre of this book: mini book as decoration, not for actual browsing pleasure, let alone reading pleasure. Total bummer.

title: Okay
text: This product fell a little short of my expectations. Franklin Covey normally puts out high quality material, but this one doesn't quite live up to their standard,

title: 0/5 Stars 🍅
text:
Uhm…did I read the same book as the rest of you? I don’t understand the positive reviews because this is the worst book I’ve ever read in my life. All the main characters do it eat! And kiss!

Beyond that, I was thoroughly confused by their ‘relationship.’ You know how you feel secondhand embarrassment when you witness something really cringy? That’s how I felt every single time the two main characters had a conversation. The main character spoke to the man more like he was her son, not her love interest. The dialogue killed me…just absurdly horrible. If I could return this book, I would.

title: Important topics to explore
text:
It was nice to read a book that really dug into the mind of a person with strong feelings, who really allowed themselves to feel them all. I think it’s in important thing to explore and is very much needed.

I enjoyed watching the main character grow

title: Strange combination of cultures
text: Crazy mixture of Oklahoma culture and Paris France . Bonita only kills when there's no other way to solve the problem.

title: Graphic and Disturbing
text:
I'll start this review with a warning. The Girl in the Road contains some very graphic scenes in terms of both sex and violence. While that's not my cup of tea, I can handle it up to a point. Unfortunately, this book went far beyond that point; there is one brief but highly disturbing scene involving an adult engaging in sexual acts with a young child. For me, that is just too much, and it is not anything I ever want to read in a book.

That being said, if you can handle extremely disturbing sexual situations and violent scenes, you might find you really enjoy this book. Up until that particular scene I mentioned above, I was quite happy with The Girl in the Road. There is an intensity in the narration that draws the reader in, and the skyrocketing levels of desperation and urgency make it difficult to put the book down.

The story was unique, compelling, and addictive, but the content wasn't right for me. Without the incredibly disturbing scene, I would have given this 4 stars, but with it I'm bringing it down to just 2.

title: The story line was good, though I would have liked to see a ...
text: The story line was good, though I would have liked to see a little more character developement and interaction. Needed some more editing. Al in all it was still a good read.

title: Two Stars
text: Had to return. Plan pictures. Did not like

title: A bit dramatic
text:
Pros:
*Characters were interesting, sad we didn't get to know Chloe more.
*Plot was interesting and I thought her take on the mermaid/merman legend was very interesting. The physical similarities really stood out, and the abilities were cool to read about. I like that she explained some of their history and how their society works, where they live, how they've managed to stay hidden for so long, etc.

Cons:
*The main character's mother was confusing to me. I suppose she'll be explained in further detail in the following books, especially considering what we learn at the end of the book, but as it is in this one, she seemed to flip back and forth and her reactions to some things were unusual (some readers may point out that that too could be attributed to her secret but considering how long she has lived the way she does, I don't buy it). And actually I felt that way about a few characters - they made dramatic shifts in mood and opinions, and some of their reasoning didn't really make sense.
*Predictable. Emma wasn't that much of a mystery to me. In fact I spent most of the book wondering why it took Galen and the other characters so long to figure out what she was and why. Heck it had to basically be pointed out to them.
*I get that grieving is different for everyone and some time has passed, but I thought that Emma's overall reaction to the loss of her best and seemingly only friend was a bit well, it flipped back and forth. At first it seemed very realistic but then Galen showed up and it was like she forgot except for very few later points in the book that were used to further the plot.
*Based on what I know about shark attacks, I would say that this one was VERY unrealistic. That should have been researched better.

On a personal note, why does everything have to be a series? Authors can't get to the point in one book anymore. I ordered three books from amazon vine all from separate authors, only one didn't turn out to be the first in a series. I get it, they're trying to sell more books but I think they would do better if they had less quantity and more quality.

Anyway, all in all it was a good read, passed the time. But I'm not really looking forward to the sequel.

title: Unprofessional textbook
text:
I received this book as a present from a friend.

Shortly after started reading the book, I got the impression the it hasn't been written by a anatomy, gymnastics or exercise physiology expert. Indeed, it surprisingly turned out that this book's author is a physician (an orthopaedic surgeon, to be precise). As I usually admire Human Kinetics professional textbooks, I'm astonished by their agreement to publish a book that's been written by someone who clearly isn't an expert in this professional field.

I would recommend to purchase another book published by Human Kinetics or a different publisher.

title: The book tries to be more that it is
text:
This novel by Richard Grant is set before WWII, in 1937/8, in Germany and Washington DC. The author follows a set of unlikely characters involved in the shadowy world of espionage and counter-espionage. Canaris, Heydrich, plus a cast of made up characters, all play their individual parts in this story.

We follow a semi-plot of Canaris reaching out to more neutral elements in the United States, and being thwarted time and time again. We follow a US Senator, his “fixer” and his delicate son as they weave in and out of the fairly convoluted plot.

This is one of those books, to my observation, that tries to be more that it is – pointing the way towards some elusive message. So, I had a really hard time deciding if this was a three star book trying for four stars, or if it was a four star book, failing to bring in that fourth star and only getting three. In the end, since I cannot give 3.5 stars, I will settle on three.

The author speaks German, and wants to brag about that – so many phrases in German and without the following translation in English – pretentious, is my interpretation. And put in places they were not needed to move the plot along – for example – the mention that the film playing was Walt Disney’s “Schneewittchen und die sieben Zwerge” – which translates as Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs – but the author does not tell you that – I am. As far as I was concerned – unneeded level of complexity or bragging.

A pet peeve of mine is the term “gone missing” – this is a 21st century affectation – the term is “missing” – as in “the man is missing” not “the man has gone missing”, or even worse “the man went missing.” The author uses “gone missing” in this novel set in 1938 – that phrase would not have been used.

Another pet peeve of mine, people in trouble, take out enemies and then flee, and do not pick up the weapons of the fallen enemy so they have a weapon for future use – this happens when Oskar slashes the Gestapo man with the knife, and then leaves a perfectly good weapon (pistol) as they move off. At least the author has Von Ewigholz think to take the weapon from the other dead Gestapo agent, when his Walther PPK runs dry. Speaking of said PPK – Oskar carries it for several days, without ever checking to see exactly how many cartridges (note, cartridges not bullets) it contained after they had acquired it. Another pet peeve – a cartridge is the entire package – shell casing, primer, powder, and bullet – a bullet is just the lead projectile – thus it is incorrect to say how many bullets are in a weapon – the correct usage is to say how many cartridges are in the weapon.

The author has one of the SS characters in the book standing at his Berlin office on Prinz-Albrecht- Strasse in his office of the “Reich Security Main Office”. The correct term is "Reich Main Security Office”. For an author that keeps banging us over the head with German phrases, to get this wrong is very jarring.

One thing I will give the author is his correct attitude of the German people towards “jaywalking”. They do not do it. He has the comment made that the people jaywalking must be tourists. Very true – on the street in Frankfurt 20-25 years ago we watched as tourist parents took their child across the road before the light had changed, and they were yelled at by the locals saying they were setting a bad example for their child and were being bad parents. To be honest, I agreed!

A very detailed book – and it does give a fairly accurate feeling of how it feels to live in a police state where one has to watch every word spoken and care must be taken to whom one will speak freely, even when there is supposedly no one listening. After all, being paranoid is not crazy when there really are people out there trying to get you. Just ask most any student on a University Campus today.

An interesting book – it won’t be for everyone – and as I said right between a 3 and 4 star rating.

title: Meh.
text: I feel like this book had some good, creepy imagery although it was ruined by the rape scenes. I realize the evil in this book was a demonic sex cult so it would have been hard to keep rape out of it but it still felt unnecessary. The characters lacked depth so it was hard to care about them.

title: Kills Brain Cells
text:
Most stupid book I've ever read. Warning, minor spoilage.

Main character Rachel devolves to bratty pouty self centered immature person and yet mary sue like is embraced and praised by fictional persons of reknown despite having done absolutely nothing to truly earn their admiration. Contrived main plot of out of the blue human hate group miraculously never mentioned so much in passing in 9 previous books despite being some big deal that every Inderlander knows about like their version of the boogyman. HAPA apparently makes the IS crazy paranoid and willing to paste responsibility for their terrorist like crimes on hapless Inderlanders with possible means if no reasonable motive or other logical underpinnings.

Gee someone is trying to make artificial demons! Lets pin this on someone who has the means to actually make REAL demons, bwah ha haaaa... we IS r so smart!!! Add into the fact that previously known Inderlander prejudiced humans on FIB are pulled into a joint effort with IS to help pull down the big bad HAPA who despite their trying to be blatant with their crimes and gain public recognition and abilities to kick both IS and FIB and Rachel's collective rear ends continuously and gleefully... somehow miss the bright light bulb every other terrorist group has of informing the media and taking credit for their big bad terrorist acts.

Stupid add on sprinkles - supposedly ancient powerful vamp who can't even control the living vampire he's riding. really? Slave trader elf abducting responsible for a 1000 years of pain and suffering for Ceri, AL the demon being allowed to play with the elf babies? REALLY?!?! the one bright spot of giving Ivy a love/blood relationship, then yanking it out from under her in the last couple pages in the book. Rachel learning some really important information about Black Ops groups and enjoying the crush like glow in sharing the "secret" with Trent, instead of say informing her deeply close friends and business partners Ivy and Jenks.

Most of the book is act of stupidity followed by more stupidity of Rachel, and everyone but the crazed and ranting HAPA cell of terrorists who inexplicably trounce IS and FIB over and over. Oh, and Rachel finally realizes, gee might be some human who hate inderlanders helping HAPA working in FIB at the very very end of the book. Something blatantly obvious that clearly never occurred to ANYONE ELSE the entire rest of the book.

Ow. This book made my brain hurt. I could feel it killing IQ points as I read it. I honestly could not believe someone who gave us such wonderful first books in this series could do such poor plotting and actually expected anyone with working intellect to swallow this... omg it was so bad :(

title: Light beach read
text: This was a decent beach read that we read for one of my book clubs.  Its a simple book.  We generated a decent conversation, but there was no debate, deep thinking, or complex discussion.  I won't bother reading another book by this author because there are so many outstanding books out there.  No need to waste more time.

One serious nit to pick, though: if the author didn't know enough to not use "splatter" for "spatter," then his editor(s) didn't do their job.

His interactions with women and people on the island were pretty insignificant. This book was just too scatterbrained, too boring, and too desperate. title: You can get this online for free!
text: This is a good source to learn Croatian but had I known you could simply look this entire manual up on the FSI website and also listen to the lessons there, I would not have bothered to purchase it! This should not be sold when it is online for free. All you get is the CD so it's not like they have at least printed the manual for you to spare you the cost of the paper. You have to print it yourself. That said, it's a good resource but it's also very old. The language has likely evolved a great deal since then. I believe this was produced in the 1960's. Overall, I'm glad I have it because I love languages and find it interesting to have this resource.

title: Nothing Particularly Special
text:
Author: Alyson Noel
Pages: 320
Source: Purchased from Barnes and Noble
Standalone of Series: 1st in Series

Since a horrible accident claimed the lives of her family, sixteen-year-old Ever can see auras, hear people's thoughts, and know a person's life story by touch. Going out of her way to shield herself from human contact to suppress her abilities has branded her as a freak at her new high school--but everything changes when she meets Damen Auguste...
Ever sees Damen and feels an instant recognition. He is gorgeous, exotic and wealthy, and he holds many secrets. Damen is able to make things appear and disappear, he always seems to know what she's thinking--and he's the only one who can silence the noise and the random energy in her head. She doesn't know who he really is--or what he is. Damen equal parts light and darkness, and he belongs to an enchanted new world where no one ever dies.
* * *

Evermore was simply another fish in the current of mainstream paranormal romance. Admittedly, the idea of Alchemy is not a great deal common, but there are the unavoidable stereotypes that hold true throughout all of today's YA Paranormal Fantasy.

The unearthly beautiful boy who captivates the female protagonist with his unique looks and debonair charm that NO other man could ever equate to.
The main female character that is utterly defenseless when it comes to her love interest. (See above example.)
The mundane bitch who's only goal in life is to see the leading lady fall flat on her love struck little ass.
The inhuman bitch who is out to kill our leading lady, for xyz reasons.

The list goes on. Really, it does.

But, Evermore was a good read. I can't take that away from Alyson Noel. She knows how to write a captivating story that does leave you wanting more. I can see where the Twilight comparisons come in, but, really, look at Evermore for what it is: A fun read.

Ever was kind of bratty, I thought. She was too stuck in the past, not even trying to move forward with her life. She alienated everyone, even her two best friends Miles and Haven. I understand she lost her family in a car accident, but she won't even give her aunt the gratitude she deserves for taking care of Ever. And then, of course, classic case of crush on the mysterious hot new guy...

I do recommend it to anyone not looking for anything not already done before, but is still a good book.

Plot: 3/5
Cover: 5/5
Writing: 4/5
Uniqueness: 4/5
Characters: 3.5/5

title: Poirot on the case again
text: Hercule Poirot is on vacation and meet a couple by the name of Opalsen. Mrs. Opalsen wears lots of jewelry and goe to get a pearl necklace to show Poirot and it turns out the necklace has been stolen. It's up tp Hastings and Poirot to solve the mystery. This is a nice short story.

title: Decent, but takes to long to hook you, and has flaws
text:
I really enjoyed the first book in this series, but this one was not as gripping. The author failed to expand the interesting world he developed, instead populating it with some cliched characters who didn't seem to bring any freshness to the story. They seem to move the story along alright, but this suffers from a phenomenon common in trilogies: The first installment is great, and brings an interesting new world and plot to the fore, and the next two books are only one complete story, but stretched out over two books worth of pages with a cliffhanger in the middle.

As for the plot itself, it is just *slow* and a bit repetitive, and significant portions of it involve characters I just didn't care about. By the time the author got to the interesting part, it was the end of the book, and I was only then getting really engaged with the read. It made me think that if he had edited the story better, this and the next book would make a very good single book, but as is, is only a decent read.... well written, but flawed.

As the first book is being made into a movie, I will be curious to see if the story benefits from the mandatory editing and shortening of a film adaptation.

title: I don't see this helping
text:
This does not help students.

There are fundamental flaws with the ICTS Basic Skills Test system period.
It is not a cheap test to take - it is not covered by grants or scholarships, it is pretty much
out of pocket.

You can use this prep material, the prep material on the ICTS website, or any of the host of other
ICTS 300 test prep books available, but it won't help you.

Why? Because you will never know what you missed on the test.
That's right. ICTS only gives you your numeric score and a pass/fail graph results.
Each test section you took has a results page. They all lead to the exact same page, which is only the graph and number (like Reading - 199). You will never be allowed to see your test answers, never allowed to know what areas in which you are weak.
This is a huge flaw. ICTS claims they can't give back test results because people would cheat. Sounds to me like the only ones cheating are the folks at ICTS. They cheat the students out of any real help this way.

Let's say you scored 180 on the math out of a possible 300 (and the needed 240). Okay, you missed the goal by at least 60 points.
So, where is your weakness? Instead of results that even go so far as to say you got 80% of the algebra questions right, 40% of the geometry questions right and 75% of the basic math right, you get a blanket number with no breakdown. You won't know if you are weak in geometry or some other area. You might have had a perfect score on all the geometry, but messed up the algebra questions, and need to review algebra. You'll never know.

As it is, this is a nice financial racket for ICTS, but only milks the students. The Basic Skills 300 is very expensive to take.
The majority of students now fail this test after the Sep 2010 changes. I don't think a whole set of students suddenly got dumber, but that is what this test would lead someone to think. It keeps a lot of very good students out of their desired major, because without a score of at least 240 on each of the sections of this test, you cannot get into the education programs. Wanted to be a teacher since you were in elementary yourself? Can't think of anything else you've ever wanted to do? well, time to rethink your life, because Illinois has decided for you that if you can't pass their test with random hidden scoring, you can't possibly teach.

What this test DOES do is show who can test well, or who is fresh out of high school.
Those people who love tests as a challenge or personal game to be won will love it. The white-knuckle testers, those
who break out into a sweat when they hear the word "test" will likely fail.
Those who are recent high school graduates will have all of this sort of data fresh on their minds, and probably do okay.
If you are older, it has been a while since you were in school and you want to go back for a teaching certificate
now that your kids are older, good luck with passing! You probably won't be able to get certified in Illinois. After all, there is a
shortage of teachers, IL certainly does not rank highly in national testing results, so instead of helping more students
get into good programs, they keep them at arm's length and lock them out. There are people with master's degrees who cannot
pass this test. Of course, they won't know why either, because of the ICTS policy of not sharing ANYTHING about your test results
with you except the grand total.

Until ICTS can help students know WHAT they missed so they can study harder, it is a total shot in the dark, and both a waste
of money and time. The education programs in the state of Illinois are already very limited in scope and in the amount of space for students. They don't put education as a priority here, in my opinion. I didn't grow up here, thank goodness. But my spouse who did still is lacking in some very basic skills. Much like many states are doing, teachers teach to meet federal funding guidelines, rather than making sure all students have the skills they are trying to teach. They have a tight timeline and can't really spend the time with students like they should - the principal will be on their backs about meeting the school goals for federal funds.
So, ICTS helps to feed the un-education machine here by putting this test as a requirement, with nothing but practice tests to go on - there is NOTHING a student can do to help find out what they are missing on the tests. NOTHING. So, students continue to practice a broad variety of skills in hopes of passing it the next time they take it. Good luck - it's another random shot. You'll still not know what you missed or didn't miss - only the little black and white graph that will tell you if you tested good enough to apply to an education program.

So, to sum up, if you don't pass the test the first time, you won't know why. You can, however, pay even more money out to ICTS for another chance to waste a morning several months later, long after you need to have passed. You can't get into the IL education programs to help you learn to be an effective teacher until you can prove you already know everything and don't need the program.
Yep - if you can do a great job on the test and already HAVE all the skills, then we'll let you into the education program, and you can spend the next two or three years taking classes that might or might not help you actually be a good teacher. But hey - it's only money and time. Those are both endless, right? Right? (And I think we've all had teachers that were very smart themselves, probably passed this test with a great score, but who can't manage to communicate the subject matter to the students, or who makes the students hate the subject after being in one of their classes! What a waste of human resources - this test rules out a lot of very good people who are not strong test takers.)

This test proves NOTHING except showing who is good at taking tests.
It shows NOTHING about the potential to be a great teacher.
You can practice until you see test questions in your sleep, but you still will never know what you need to work on, because
ICTS keeps it all a secret.

title: I was not captivated!
text:
This book is about the bravery of the American Presidents from 1789 to 1989, and how they changed and shaped American policy.

I didn't much enjoy reading this book. I liked the chapters on George Washington and Lincoln (probably because I have read their biographies), but wasn't captivated enough by the stories of the other presidents. I didn't find bravery in many of the stories. Some presidents did shape US policy, but that in itself is not bravery! It was more like self-preservation. I also didn't like the author's style of writing. Furthermore, the chapters are not broken down by the name of presidents, so it is difficult to use this book as a cross-reference.

I would have liked to see chapters on Clinton and Bush junior. Why did the author choose presidents up to 1989 only? Why not up to the present day? This book was after all published in 2007, so Clinton and Bush could have been included.

title: this was not one of his better efforts, but it could have been
text: I've read all of Dick Francis' books and (I believe) also all of those of his son Felix.  While Felix has done an admirable job following in his father's footsteps, this was not one of his better efforts, but it could have been.  The story was interesting and moving along quite well for most of the book.  He did a very good job of getting local details correct which shows excellent research.  Where he misses the boat is on the ending.  It was extremely rushed and felt like he just cobbled something together to be done with it.  It really was a tremendous let down and not at all in keeping with what we have come to expect from the Francis franchise of books.

title: The early material is great, but Niven's latest is awful
text:
In 1966 Larry Niven created the ultimate tourist with his short story "Neutron Star." It was the tale of Beowulf Shaeffer, a laid-off pilot heavily in debt and easy to blackmail, and how the alien race the puppeteers convinced him to make a dangerous flyby of a neutron star. Throughout the late sixties followed several other Beowulf Shaeffer stories, which were previously to be found only in the out-of-print collection NEUTRON STAR. In 1994 Del Rey released CRASHLANDER, which brought back into print the Beowulf Shaeffer stories of the late 60's, together with "The Borderland of Sol" (1975), a new story "Procrustes," and interim material that Niven had just penned to bind the stories together into one novel, as it were (there's no table of contents and the title of each story isn't listed at the head of the page). CRASHLANDER has some good material, but the latest writing shows that Niven's treatment of his Known Space universe has become very poor indeed.
The late-60's Beowulf Shaeffer stories were classics of science fiction, mixing hard science with colourful alien races and futuristic fashion. In "Neutron Star" the reader travels with Shaeffer as he visits what was then a revolutionary concept in astronomy. In "At the Core", the puppeteers convince Shaeffer to take an experimental hyperdrive all the way to the galactic core, where he makes a discovery that spurs the puppeteers into fleeing Known Space. "Flatlander" begins with Shaeffer as a tourist on Earth, and takes him on a journey with a millionaire to a very unusual planet. "Grendel", the last of the golden age of the Shaeffer stories, has Shaeffer foil a kidnapping on a newly-colonized world. These stories are all excellent and are recommended reading for any fan of science fiction.
The last two stories, however, are incredibly disappointing, nearly enough so to taint the eariler works. "The Borderland of Sol" was written after the decline of Niven's writing in the mid-1970's. It nearly repeats the theme of "Grendel" (with Shaeffer becoming something of a detective), but with unbelievable characters, B-movie shoot-outs, and uninspired futurisms. The last story, "Procrustes" dates from the 1990's and is nearly as bad as Niven's novel from the same time THE RINGWORLD THRONE. "Procrustes" has a plot that is convoluted to say the least, and none of the characters act like they have in previous stories. Most disturbing is the Robert Heinlein-esque turn into sexuality explicit scenes that Niven made in the early 90's, as "Procrustes" begins with an orgy. The frame stories were written at the same time as "Procrustes" are are just as bad. They contradict previous Niven stories (such as mentioning the Trinocs when they won't be met for another 200 years, the Puppeteer Fleet of Worlds, etc.) and end in an inexplicable murder that is nothing but a deus-ex-machina.
My recommendation: skip CRASHLANDER and find the out-of-print collection NEUTRON STAR, which brings together all the golden age Shaeffer stories as well as several other fascinating Known Space short stories.
