title: A well-written example of a familiar formula
text:
1. Find a little-known but gripping historical event, so the reader will learn something - in this case, the horrific “round-up” and deportation of Parisian Jews in July of 1942
2. In the context of this event, put a child/children at risk – in this case, easy, as over 4000 children were swept up in the Round-up in order to make the numbers demanded by the German overlords.
3. Crank up the suspense by putting one character at special risk – in this case, Sarah’s little brother whom Sarah has hidden in a locked cupboard – will he be discovered? Allowed to live? Or die of thirst and hunger in the cupboard?
4. Create a modern character who somehow gets involved with the historical event, and who has issues also – in this case, an American expatriate journalist with a philandering French husband
5. Alternate between the two threads so that you leave a cliff-hanger on one thread while you revert to the other thread (Dickens and other writers of serials were good at this!)
6. Inject a love interest late in the story so that while one thread ends in doom the other might promise a happy ending.
And there you have “Sarah’s Key”! If you like this kind of book, you will like this book.

title: Hit or Miss short stories
text:
Okay. Real talk.

I didn't realize that more than half of this was Wicked Lovely short stories. I didn't enjoy those. I don't enjoy the Wicked Lovely books. When I bought this it was off the shelf and I don't know if I missed it or what but I personally assumed there would be some in there but not over half. I could be blind. That said, I'm not including those in my three-star rating since I'm already biased.

The ones I that were unrelated were half enjoyable and half not. That's the truth for me. But I know there are some die-hard fans out there and I don't want to discount this for them. I just think that if Melissa Marr is hit or miss for you that this collection is going to be the same way.

title: meandering and drawn out
text: great character development, but you never get a sense of what made them fall in love. they seemed to be friends for the entire story and all the sudden they are in love, but not a deep passionate love. this was very difficult and tedious to read and i couldn't wait to finish it so i could move on to something else. btw,the ending was atrocious. for great romance, diana gabaldon and marsha canham rule.

title: Interesting but forgettable
text: I love that this novel did not focus on the Jewish people, but rather the German people and a child at that.  But, the death narrator bothered me a lot as my mind began to wander about him ... like,  if he's death why does he have to physically climb through windows, why is he telling me the ending, why is Leisel so special that he chose her to write about, etc.  He also seemed to put distance between me as reader and the main characters.  The result was that I felt little for these characters, interesting as they were.  It was very well-written and had a great plot, but Mr. Death ruined it for me.

title: Why did I waste my time? SPOILER
text:
This was my first and last by Lisa Scottline. This book is a jumbled up mess. It started off good and kept my interest but went downhill. The first 3/4 of the book are the court case and what happened in the weeks before the court case. It was drawn out way too long and got boring. I almost stopped reading about halfway through but decided to trudge on thinking it might get better. It didn't.

This book is not what I would call a thriller by any means. Well, I was thrilled when it was over but that's not the point.

!!SPOILER ALERT!!!

The book is about a stepdad (Noah) and his court case of the murder of his step daughter. This goes every other chapter, along with the mother (Maggie) and her point of view.

The story goes along very slowly until we find out the step daughter wasn't really the step daughter but an imposter. The real daughter was kidnapped and put in a sex traffic ring. WTH? All of this happens in the last few pages. There was no mention of anything suspicious (besides the murder) until the very end and it was all jammed in 30 pages or so. It was like she added the last chapters of a different book onto this one. It would have been more interesting if this storyline was presented much earlier on.

There were also a few chapters about Noah and his experiences in jail. This added nothing at all to the story and could have been left out completely. I'm not sure where she was going with those chapters but she shouldn't have went there.

Glad it's over, won't read another!

title: Definitely not an intimate biography!
text: Book hardly spoke about the person, more a sketch of her whereabouts. Really turned me off quickly.

title: Pretty to look at but leaves one wanting more!
text:
Pro's: (1) Small and compact yet 2000 pages- very convenient! (2) Leather and looks nice! (3) Nice, yet limited selection of scriptural and non-scriptural readings. (4) Better translations of the hymns from the Liturgia Horarum than in the Catholic Book Publishing LoTH. (5) Opportunity to try something new if bored with LoTH?!

Con's: (1) Uses the Grail Psalter - blahhhhhh! (2) Uses NRSV translation for scriptural texts! Blahhhhhh! Just say it....'man', not 'person'. Inclusive language will be the death of linguistic beauty former generations cherished. I am not happy with the ICEL's bland translation of the LoTH by CBP, but it is more the norm in the Church and provides greater variety of readings. It was said of ICEL "Half know Latin, but know no English...the other half know English, but know no Latin!" But I digress...(3) Does not provide all psalms of the psalter, only 100 or so! And many of those have been redacted and shortened. (4) The compiler/editor is a Lutheran! No offense, I want my Catholic stuff from faithful Catholics! He may play with the Benedictines up in Minnesota but that doesn't make him suited to compile and offer texts for Catholics to use. (5) Uses a one week psalter instead of two (or four if you prefer). (6)Done in conjunction with Benedictines in Collegville, MN. They are not a hotbed for strict liturgical orthodoxy. (7) If you are a more traditional leaning Catholic don't even bother.

In the end I will stick with the 4-volume Liturgy of the Hours and Fr. Peter Stravinskas' Lauds and Vespers: Latin-English Enlarged Edition (Latin and English Edition). Feel it is better to pray with the Church in Her official texts as Pius Parsch recommended.

title: Terrible, Unless You're Looking for an Example of How NOT to Write
text: I have made my living as a professional writer for 30 years, and I can definitively say this is absolutely the worst manual on writing I have ever written. Pyne has some good ideas in here, but they are pretty much the ideas you would find in most writing manuals. The difference is that Pyne buries them in a heaping mass of prose, so his good ideas are easy to miss. What is ironic is that he writes disdainfully about writing tight. I see why he does not care for that approach; he cannot do it. The worst thing about this book is not the lardy writing, though; it's that Pyne uses extended similies and/or metaphors in virtually every paragraph. The resulting prose is exhausting and confusing. This tome is a perfect example of how NOT to write.

title: A highwayscribery "Book Report"
text:
One of the nice aspects to being sick, and there is a silver lining in just about anything, is that you, if so inclined, can get a lot of reading done. We're talking mildly sick here; sick so that you drift in and out of swoons induced by stuff you can buy over the counter. the scribe's Nyquil years are mostly behind him and reveries during this recent lay-up were fueled by Alka-Seltzer flu medicine, benadryl, and Vitamin-C powder packets.

the highway scribe scarfed down a good number of books and reports on them will be spread out over the next few weeks. First to be finished off was "The Muckrakers," which was edited back in 1961 by Arthur and Lila Weinberg.

The tome contains actual writings of the famed muckrakers who wrote in the first decade of the last century. Their specialty was uncovering abuses. Those abuses could be committed by labor unions, or government officials, or a church, but mostly they worked to bust up the concentration of wealth as represented in the giant corporate trusts that had surfaced 20 or 30 years before.

President Theodore Roosevelt termed the expression, "muckrakers" in a speech that was largely critical of the era's journalists who were, otherwise, mostly on his side, or at least shared the same goals of reform and a cleaner running system.

Among the offerings in "The Muckrakers" is the very speech in which Roosevelt coined the expression. He drew it from Bunyan's "Pilgrim's Progress" and "the description of the Man with the Muckrake, the man who could look no way but downward, with a muckrake in his hands; who was offered a celestial crown, but continued to rake to himself the filth of the floor."

TR went on to preach caution to those leading the crusade and called for an even-handedness that would inform, but not inflame.

As they say, the name stuck.

The book spends some time on the atmosphere in which the muckrakers were born. It talks about the growth of mass circulation magazines such as "McClures" and "Cosmopolitan" that took it upon themselves to finance investigative reporters and publish their in-depth revelations to much scandle and positive affect.

Each section (The City, The State, Pure Food, Child Labor, etc.) is framed with a perusal of the issue at the time, and of a profile on the writer who did the work. Among these names are Lincoln Steffens, Ida Tarbell, Ray Stannard Baker, Upton Sinclair, and Mark Sullivan.

the scribe pulled the book for purposes related to his career as a journalist. It's good to know what pioneers like this did and why. But coming to this book is a little like sampling Elvis after being raised on Pink Floyd. You're not going to see the novelty in it; and from their novelty were the muckrakers' powers drawn.

This kind of reporting is done today in any number of weeklies and monthly's on the right and left; "Harpers," "Atlantic Monthly," "The New Republic," "National Review," and so on. The techniques have hardly changed. This book is about how the groundwork was laid.

What's better and more useful about this collection of magazine articles are the portraits they render of the country in that time. It is a raw powerhouse sprawling its industrial self across a giant and empty continent, mostly lawless, if very Christian.

The essays connect the dots on how the great fortunes of the era - Frick, Vanderbilt, Morgan etc.- were built largely through the acquisition of what was supposedly the public trust. They tell the story of child labor to the tunes of millions across the southern textile belt. The muckrakers spun sturdy yarns of corrupt city machines and detailed even the battles for territory, or the love lives, of immigrant newsboys from the street.

It is hard to tell whether such an era of excess and abuse of public trust is a reflection on our own times, or if times simply don't change; that for all our pomp and circumstance, being a thug pays best.

There was a law back in those times, that prevented people from leaving government to lobby the same place he just worke.

What happened to that?

The work/slave conditions documented by William Hard and Edwin Marshall are not gone, just shipped overseas.

You can be a television cameraman and be killed in Baghdad hotel by U.S. forces, or you can reveal the secrets of a seedy senate and be mysteriously assassinated like David Graham Phillips was for articles reproduced in "The Muckrakers."

Two pieces at the back of the book, "De Kid Wot Works at Night," and "The City of Chicago: A Study of the Great Immoralities," create a rather staggering portrait of the crazy town on the lake at the height of its power.

This Chicago is teeming and active to the outskirts, a city created along mass industrial lines where the human element was something of an afterthought. The city's largest business is vice, providing cheap (as in money) girls and cheap beer to the great swathes of workerdom serving the meat industry, the railroad, the ironworks, shipping. The girls are innocents pruned from the immigrant class and their trafficking is handled out of a city police department.

And for all that, the actions government took in response, the attention paid by the general population to the muckrackers' message, are far beyond anything we might to expect today in terms of reform. The ink-stained wretches do not tread upon the feet of corporate titans they way they did then. They will not impose the will of the state over industry. Teddy Roosevelt, a Republican when blacks voted Republican, did.

And America listened to its muckrakers, rather than label them, and acted according to their recommendations. "The Muckrakers" as a book shows us what that interaction meant, and what has been lost between the press and its audience.

title: Disappointing - not what I thought it would be
text:
I wanted to like this. It included three of my favorite things: classic movies, RPGs, and what specifically caught my eye about this title, explorations of how to enhance RPGs with storytelling principles.

Instead, 88% of the content was spent analyzing a few hundred individual beats, one by one, over and over, across three fixed texts. Spoiler alert: Stories have ups and downs.

But what do you do with your beat analysis? How do you apply beat analysis as a GM?

The section that finally got around to that - the reason I bought the book - amounted to less than 1% of the book's content. There are a few general comments and suggestions, and that's it. The book doesn't drill down into methods or techniques for applying beat analysis to RPGs. There are no worked examples of planning or running scenarios for an RPG.

How about applying the beat idea as a player? Well, no, it seems, because it would be "a massive feat of passive-aggressiveness" and "appalling" to look at a GM's story beats. Wow, all that content about beat analysis, including encouragements for you to try it yourself, but suddenly it's appalling to have these thoughts as a player.

Maybe you'd enjoy this book if you want to see a point-by-point deconstruction of Hamlet, Dr. No, or Casablanca because that's what this book mostly is.

title: Must Be Me
text:
"In The Company Of Angels", seems to have captured the feeling of others who have written about the book. N.M. Kelby certainly has written a charming short story but I fail to see what the fuss is about.
The locale she sets her story in is charming, and the metaphors she creates from the town's product are for the most part well done. But there was nothing in this tale that has not appeared in a variety of other forms, and has not taken place during this ever-popular time period.
I appear to be in the minority here, but I found the story too familiar, and at times a bit too precious
